Headline: Examensarbete, dammsäkerhet – spridning av lärdomar från incidenter
Subject: Electrical Engineering
Description:
Affärsverket Svenska kraftnät (Svk) har till uppgift att på ett affärsmässigt sätt förvalta, driva och utveckla ett kostnadseffektivt, driftsäkert och miljöanpassat kraftöverföringssystem, sälja överföringskapacitet samt i övrigt bedriva verksamheter som är anknutna till kraftöverföringssystemet.

En av Svenska kraftnäts myndighetsuppgifter är att främja dammsäkerheten i landet. Vi verkar för en framtid med god dammsäkerhet och samordnad beredskap för dammhaveri. Vi bidrar till nationell samordning genom tydliga krav, vägledning och information. Vi verkar även för ökad kunskap och kompetens inom området genom att bidra till utbildning, teknik- och metodutveckling.

Bakgrund
Dammars förmåga att dämma och utestänga stora mängder vatten bidrar till grundläggande samhällsfunktioner inom elförsörjning, vattenreglering och översvämningsskydd. Det dämda vattnet innebär dock en potentiell fara om dammen skulle haverera. För att undvika ett dammhaveri krävs därför en välbyggd och väldimensionerad damm, men människorna och den organisation som driver och sköter dammen är minst lika avgörande.

Allvarliga dammolyckor i Sverige är sällsynta, men det inträffar återkommande incidenter. Lärdomar från egna och andras incidenter, inklusive åtgärdsplaner och utfall, är då viktiga underlag för att förbättra och utveckla sin egen verksamhet. Idag saknas ett system för att samla och systematiskt dela erfarenheter, utan dessa sprids istället muntligt. Exempelvis är dammägare skyldiga att rapportera incidenter gällande dammsäkerheten till länsstyrelsen i det län där dammen är belägen, och grupperingar av dammägare delar ofta erfarenheter med varandra. För att lärdomar och erfarenheter ska bli användbara för många krävs dock ett fungerande incidentrapporteringssystem och metoder för att dela erfarenheterna.

En av svårigheterna i att upprätta ett fungerande incidentrapporteringssystem för dammsäkerhet är målkonflikten mellan erfarenhetsdelning och att viss information behöver skyddas. Internationellt är det vanligt med nationella incidentrapporteringssystem för dammsäkerhet. Andra länders system kan ge en bra vägledning kring vilken information som kan delas, men systemen är överlag inte automatiskt tillämpningsbara utifrån svensk kontext och lagstiftning. För vägledning kring utformning av system är det därför lämpligt att studera vilka former som används för incidentrapportering och erfarenhetsdelning av svenska myndigheter som bedriver säkerhetskänslig verksamhet.

Uppdraget
Syftet med detta projekt är föreslå lämplig modell för att samla och sprida lärdomar från dammsäkerhetsincidenter. Förslaget bör utgå från tekniska och organisatoriska förutsättningar inom dammsäkerhet och särskilt belysa hur och vilka incidenter och erfarenheter som kan delas öppet. Modellen bör även inkludera möjlighet att samla och sprida internationella dammsäkerhetsincidenter. Projektet genomförs i fyra steg:

Kunskapsinhämtning rörande internationella och svenska dammar och tänkbara skadeförlopp.
Sammanställning av hur information och lärdomar från dammsäkerhetsincidenter sammanställs och delas i andra länder.
Sammanställning och beskrivning av svenska myndigheters incidentrapporteringssystem (inom andra farliga verksamheter och naturolyckor).
Analys och framtagande av förslag på ett svenskt arbetssätt för spridning av lärdomar från dammsäkerhetsincidenter.
I det första steget inhämtas grundläggande kunskaper om dammar internationellt och i Sverige, samt förekommande skadeförlopp och olyckstyper. Fokus bör ligga på händelseförlopp som leder till dammhaveri, och dammar med betydande haverikonsekvenser.

Headline: Examensarbete, Transmissionsnätets påverkan på och bidrag till ekosystemtjänster
Subject: Electrical Engineering
Description:
Svenska kraftnät är systemansvarig myndighet och transmissionsnätägare med stora investeringsplaner. I vår roll säkerställer vi ett driftsäkert kraftsystem och ett personsäkert transmissionsnät. Därmed bidrar vi till att möjliggöra den gröna energiomställningen.

Genom vår verksamhet påverkar vi samhället socialt, miljömässigt och ekonomiskt, dels lokalt och nationellt, men också globalt genom våra leverantörskedjor. Vi strävar ständigt efter att analysera och hantera vår påverkan i syfte att maximera det positiva och minimera det negativa.

Enheten Hållbarhet har i uppdrag att ansvara för samordning och utveckling av Svenska kraftnäts arbete med hållbarhetsfrågor.

Vår ambition är att utveckla och förbättra arbetet med verkets väsentliga hållbarhetsaspekter, dvs. de områden där vi har störst möjlighet att bidra till en hållbar utveckling:

Hållbar och säker elförsörjning (kärnuppdraget)
Klimat
Biologisk mångfald
Jämställdhet, mångfald och ett hållbart arbetsliv
Hållbara inköp
Statstjänstemannakultur och arbete mot oegentligheter, mutor och korruption
Dialog och samverkan med samhället på alla nivåer
Främjande av forskning, utveckling och innovation
Bakgrund
Ekosystemtjänster är alla produkter och tjänster som ekosystem ger oss människor och som bidrar till vår välfärd och livskvalitet.” - Naturvårdsverket

Naturvården har utvecklats från att fokusera på skydd av exceptionella naturområden till att arbeta brett med hur vi påverkar naturmiljön i stort, inklusive det så kallade vardagslandskapet. Utmaningen idag är att hitta ett hållbart sätt att använda naturresurserna och bygga samhället utan att för den skull förstöra förutsättningarna för de ekosystemtjänster som vi är beroende av.

Svenska kraftnät är mitt uppe i en period av omfattande utveckling av transmissionsnätet för att möjliggöra energiomställningen. Samtidigt pågår det nödvändiga arbetet med att byta ut anläggningar som nåt sin livslängd vilket gör att vi befinner oss i det inledande skedet av en mycket intensiv byggnationsperiod.

Det talas ofta om att tillståndsprocesserna måste effektiviseras för att möjliggöra en snabbare ut- och ombyggnad av elnätet. Samtidigt är det viktigt att vår verksamhet inte medför större negativ miljöpåverkan än nödvändigt. För att underlätta arbetet med tillståndsprocesserna, där bland annat bedömningen av olika alternativs miljöpåverkan är ett viktigt moment, behövs bra kunskapsunderlag och lättanvända verktyg.

Svenska kraftnät ser ett behov av ökad kunskap om hur verksamheten påverkar ekosystemtjänster, negativt respektive positivt. Större kunskapsunderlag i frågan förväntas underlätta arbetet i enskilda projekt, till exempel vid bedömning av behov av utredningar, skyddsåtgärder och alternativ.

Med mer kunskap om transmissionsnätets påverka men även bidrag till ekosystemtjänster blir det även enklare för Svenska kraftnät att kommunicera och tydliggöra verkets hållbarhetsarbete externt och därmed skapa starkare förtroende i samhället.

Uppdraget
Examensarbetets syfte är att utreda och analysera vilka ekosystemtjänster som transmissionsnätet påverkar och/eller är beroende av. Påverkan på ekosystemtjänster avser så väl negativ som positiv påverkan.

Eftersom transmissionsnätet är utbrett över stora delar av landet så är en av frågorna som examensarbetet ska svara på om det är möjligt att göra en översiktlig analys och beskrivning av de ekosystemtjänster som transmissionsnätet påverkar och hur en sådan i så fall kan utformas.

Headline: Thesis Work - Multilevel DC/AC inverters with advanced gate driver circuit in Electric Vehicles
Subject: Vehicle Engineering
Description:
Thesis Worker at Volvo Cars

Welcome to explore the world of Volvo Cars by writing your thesis with us! As a thesis worker in our organization you are supported by a supervisor who follows you during your project. All thesis projects are arranged in business critical areas and therefore you will be able to contribute to our company purpose – providing freedom to move in a safe, sustainable and personal way – from day one!

Background
In Electric Vehicles (EVs), the Electromagnetic Interference (EMI) from the DC/AC inverters must be kept below limits to meet legal requirements and to ensure full function. To reduce the EMI from power electronic devices, filters with bulky capacitors and inductors are used that consume quite a lot of space and are costly. At the same time, the electric propulsion system needs to have the highest possible efficiency; therefore, multiple methods for minimizing the inverter’s losses are utilized.

Multilevel inverters have been studied as candidates for future automotive electric drives, due to their capability to function at voltages higher than the existing 800V(dc), higher efficiency and their superior harmonic performance. This can also result in much lower EMI requiring smaller EMI filters.

Scope
The objective of the thesis work is to investigate the development of a new advanced gate driver board suitable for the Neutral-Point-Clamped (NPC) inverter, with 3- and 5-levels. This new gate driver circuit will optimize inverter efficiency and EMI performance with functionalities developed during this project.

Main tasks:
1.    Conduct literature review of already existing smart gate driver solutions for inverters and study the function of the NPC converter.
2.    Simulation and modelling part:
a.    Create a detailed SPICE model of the selected gate driver electronic circuit board.
b.    Develop a high-level model of the inverter’s control structure integrating the functionalities of the selected gate driver circuit.
3.    Design gate driver PCB board and select all needed components for an experimental setup.

Your contribution is our future
•    Electric power engineering studies or equivalent
•    Matlab/Simscape or PLECS and model-based development
•    Electric circuit modelling software knowledge, e.g., LTSpice or PSpice
•    Knowledge of PCB design software tools
•    Good English skills
•    Experience of EMC/EMI is meritorious

Duration
•    The work will start in January 2023, exact date is to be discussed
•    The duration for this thesis work is 20 weeks.
•    30 ECTS (academic credits) if in agreement with your Thesis Advisor in University
•    This thesis is suitable for 2 students working in pair (splitting task 2 between each other).
•    The work will be performed in Gothenburg

Be part of the change – apply today!
Selection will be ongoing during the application period, so do not hesitate to send in your application. Attach your CV and personal letter stating your interests within the given area and your thoughts and credentials.

Please note that due to GDPR, applications via email will not be accepted.

Please apply no later than November 15th, 2022.

If you have any additional questions regarding the thesis work, you are welcome to contact manager: Fredrik Niklasson (fredrik.niklasson.2@volvocars.com), supervisors Georgios Mademlis (georgios.mademlis@volvocars.com) and Raik Orbay (raik.orbay@volvocars.com).

Headline: Master thesis: Optimization of traction energy of Stockholm commuter trains (in collaboration with MTR & SL)
Subject: Vehicle Engineering
Description:
Background
The commuter trains are one important part of public transport for both residents and travelers, which provide a cheap and time-efficient means of transport and helps to ease congestion and pollution in urban area. Even though the commuter trains are very energy-efficient and runs on green electricity, they are still consuming a great amount of energy in operation, which is mainly used by traction and comfort-related systems. With the implementation of modern trains, much information during train operation can be recorded for analysis. To meet the goal of 15% of electricity reduction for rail traffic and minimize the operational cost for the train operator, a research project on finding solutions for a more sustainable transport (financed by Vinnova InfraSweden2030) is conducted to set up a smart and cost-effective management plan for energy saving.

Scope
The objective of the master thesis focuses on the traction-related energy of the Stockholm commuter train X60. There are many aspects which can be optimized, e.g., driving-style, timetable, train weight and operational points of the traction system, to reduce the total energy consumption and ease the burden on the power supply of the infrastructure. Some of them have been implemented and recorded. Others have been proposed and are now under consideration.
In the present master thesis, a literature study on energy usage of the traction system and the corresponding energy saving measures will be conducted. Based on the recorded sensor data and previous publications, the potential for energy saving will be analyzed and quantified by means of an energy simulation tool for rail vehicles. In the end, some proposals for energy saving of the commuter train in daily operation will be given.

Tasks
The thesis work will consist of the following tasks:
• Literature study of:
- Train traction system of passenger trains (with focus on X60),
- Means of energy saving of traction energy,
- Energy simulation of rail vehicles,
- Previous reports on this aspect
• Documentation of sensor data related to traction energy.
• Analyzing or simulating the energy saving of different measures.
• Quantifying the potential of energy saving.
• Thesis writing and presenting results orally.
These tasks might be updated while working on the project.

Contact:
KTH Zhendong Liu(zhendong@kth.se), Mats Berg(mabe@kth.se)
MTR Gerasimos Loutos(gerasimos.loutos@mtr.se), Joel Forsberg(joel.forsberg@mtr.se)
TF    Erik Dunkars (erik.dunkars@regionstockholm.se)

Headline: Explainable AI for Finance (in collaboration between SEB and KTH)
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Explainable AI for Finance: Adaptive Sampling for Counterfactual Explanations

Although the accuracy of predictions and decisions from AI/ML systems have vastly improved with their increasing sophistication and complexity, nowadays even domain experts are challenged in comprehending and retracing how a model reached a result.

 This poses a concern for (semi-)autonomous decisions that affect an individual (e.g., legally, financially, or medically). The right to explanation [1] stipulates that an individual can ask for a humanly interpretable justification in high-stakes decisions, such as a (denied) loan-application.

In the rapidly developing fields of interpretable machine learning (IML) and explainable AI (XAI) [2], a counterfactual explanation of a decision describes the smallest change that should be made to the input features
x to change the output of the model [3]. For example, a counterfactual explanation for a rejected loan applicant might be: “The application would have been approved had the person had less credit cards and not defaulted on a loan three years ago.”

The popular Wachter et al.’s algorithm [4] for producing a counterfactual explanation
x’ optimizes an objective function that balances the distance between x and
x’ with how much the model’s output changes. To avoid local minima in the optimization problem either grid-search (in the feature space) or random sampling is used to reinitialize a local hill-climbing procedure (e.g., ADAM, L-BFGS).

In this project, we aim to explore adaptive sampling techniques for reinitializing the optimization procedure [5]. That is, a new candidate for x’ is no longer sampled uniformly, but rather in proportion to how promising it appears for producing a better counterfactual explanation. A similar approach has recently been explored in [6] by researcher at J.P. Morgan AI Research.

Candidates need to be highly motivated and capable of independent work and study. Programming experience in Python and knowledge of standard ML terminology, concepts and algorithms is a must. Previous exposure
 to (Bayesian) optimization is valuable. If the project is successful, then submission for presentation at an international conference (e.g., NeurIPS or ICML) is encouraged.

Organizers: Prof. Cristian Rojas (crro@kth.se),
 Dr. Robert Mattila (robert.mattila@seb.se)


References:

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right_to_explanation

[2] https://christophm.github.io/interpretable-ml-book/

[3] Verma et al. “Counterfactual Explanations for Machine Learning: A Review” (2020)

[4] Wachter et al. “Counterfactual Explanations without Opening the Black Box: Automated Decisions and the GDPR” (2017)

[5] Garnett, “Bayesian
Optimization” (2022),
https://bayesoptbook.com/

[6] Spooner et al.
“Counterfactual Explanations for Arbitrary Regression Models” (2021)

Headline: Feldetektion för autonoma system
Subject: Electrical Engineering
Description:
FOI bedriver forskning om autonoma farkostsystem i olika domäner. Det finns ett växande behov av kunskap om metoder för att prediktera och hantera fel och farliga situationer utan mänsklig inblandning. Det ställer höga krav på övervakning av systemets inre processer och modellering av felförlopp.

Dina uppgifter:

Målet med examensarbetet är att implementera en metod för feldetektion för ett specifikt autonomt system. Metoden ska implementeras och utvärderas genom simuleringar och på ett verkligt system (UAV). Arbetet presenteras i en rapport och i en demonstration.

Din profil:

Vi söker dig som studerar till Civilingenjör på Elektroteknik, Teknisk fysik, Farkostteknik eller motsvarande. Du har erfarenhet av programmering exempelvis i C/C++, Matlab, Python och ROS. För att klara av arbetet krävs samarbets- och initiativförmåga, samt en god förståelse av matematisk modellering av dynamiska system, datadrivet och analytiskt.

Vad erbjuder vi dig?

När du gör ditt exjobb hos oss ger vi dig en god inblick i vår verksamhet, där du får arbeta i en kreativ miljö. Arbetet på FOI bedrivs i form av projekt av varierad storlek och karaktär. Att arbeta på FOI innebär ett omväxlande arbete med stor grad av frihet och krav på egna initiativ och hög kompetens. På FOI kommer du att göra ditt exjobb i en forskningsnära miljö, full av engagerade experter och handledare som stöttar dig på bästa sätt.

Arbetet kommer att ske på enheten Systemteknik vid avdelningen Försvarsteknik.
Läs gärna mer om vad vi gör: https://www.foi.se/om-foi/organisation/forsvarsteknik.html

Har vi fångat ditt intresse?

Vi vill att du ansöker om examensarbetet med ett komplett CV inklusive senaste betygsutdraget samt ett personligt brev.

Du är välkommen med frågor till Karin Kraft som nås på telefon 070 843 22 71.

Då arbetet sker på en säkerhetsklassad anläggning krävs svenskt medborgarskap. Säkerhetsprövning med registerkontroll kommer att genomföras före examensarbetet enligt säkerhetsskyddslagen (2018:585).

Löpande urval kommer att ske under ansökningstiden. Examensarbetet beräknas starta 2023-02-01

Headline: Master Thesis: Evaluate a decentralized fund protocol using mechanism design
Subject: Industrial Management
Description:
BACKGROUND

Decentralized finance (DeFi) refers to the new kinds of financial services that are released on public blockchains using smart contracts. These protocols are open for anyone to participate in and rely on game-theoretic principles to ensure trust and security rather than a legal framework. In recent years, new advancements in blockchain technology have led to the creation of decentralized versions of currency baskets, index funds, and ETFs.

A decentralized fund amasses a portfolio of tokenized assets with different weightings. The portfolio needs to be rebalanced and managed by several parties that do not necessarily trust one another. Mechanisms must be in place to ensure players use a dominant strategy that generates profit for the fund, which is perceived as fair and protects the fund from manipulation.

SCOPE

The purpose of this thesis project is to evaluate our protocol from a mechanism design perspective. We have designed rules to achieve one or more desirable outcomes. The student will analyze the likelihood of these outcomes occurring when strategic participants are playing the game. The student will use tools and methods used within algorithmic game theory to support their conclusions.

IMPACT

The problem of creating a fully decentralized fund that is open for anyone to participate in is yet to be solved. This project gives the opportunity to work on a very hard problem that can have great implications if solved correctly. The student will gain insight into a unique solution that rethinks the concept of what an investment fund is and how it should operate.

DURATION

The thesis work is planned to start in January 2023, lasting 20 weeks as per agreed with your university supervisor (the equivalent of 30 ECTS).


APPLICATION AND REQUIREMENTS

We are primarily looking for a master's thesis student specializing in game theory and financial mathematics. Other qualifying aspects include having an understanding of decentralized protocols and the performance trade-offs associated with blockchain technology. Your application should include a transcript from current studies and a CV.

Headline: Master Thesis: Evaluate the implementation and performance of a decentralized fund protocol
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
BACKGROUND

Decentralized finance (DeFi) refers to the new kinds of financial services that are released on public blockchains using smart contracts. These protocols are open for anyone to participate in and rely on game-theoretic principles to ensure security and trust. We have invented a unique protocol that amasses a portfolio of tokenized assets and allows for the creation of decentralized funds.

SCOPE

The proposed degree project entails analyzing the feasibility of implementing this protocol on a well-known public blockchain. The student will study our implementation's processing and storage requirements and the cost of executing operations. The project also involves researching the implementation of other similar protocols on different kinds of blockchain infrastructure and using that knowledge to make suggestions for improvements.

IMPACT

The problem of creating a fully decentralized fund that is open for anyone to participate in is yet to be solved. This project gives the opportunity to work on a very hard problem that can have great implications if solved correctly. The student will gain insight into a unique solution that rethinks the concept of what an investment fund is and how it should operate.

DURATION

The thesis work is planned to start in January 2023, lasting 20 weeks as per agreed with your university supervisor (the equivalent of 30 ECTS).

APPLICATION AND REQUIREMENTS

We seek a master's thesis student specializing in Computer Science or another relevant field. We primarily look for a student with expertise in developing smart contracts on public blockchains such as Ethereum. Other qualifying aspects include understanding the performance trade-offs associated with blockchain technology. Your application should include a transcript from current studies and a CV.

Headline: Master Thesis - Estimating IR-drop In Power Grids With ML
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
One of the most important challenges in Integrated Circuit (IC) design, relates to Current-Resistance(IR) drop (sometimes called voltage drop), which is the deviation of a specified supply value due to power grid non-ideal physical limitations. It must be restricted for a circuit to meet its timing target and function properly. As wires get smaller and layouts get denser, obtaining an accurate estimation of IR drop through simulation-based commercial tools is very time consuming, while fixing IR drop violations further leads to longer design cycles. Therefore, fast and accurate IR drop estimation becomes essential for reducing the time needed between design cycles. Recently several Machine-Learning-based IR drop estimators have been introduced, claiming orders-of-magnitude acceleration compared with simulations-based solutions. Early-stage design analysis can be used in conjunction with machine learning algorithms to estimate IRdrop faster with the overarching goal of producing optimized component and wire configuration recommendations, more resilient to IR drop.

What you will do

This thesis is divided into several steps and goals: to survey the literature for ML techniques suitable for estimating IR-drop, extract design configurations from provided circuits to form the IR-drop dataset, develop and evaluate this dataset against the agreed ML algorithm(s) and present the results in a technical report as well as an oral presentation at Ericsson Research.

Headline: Master Thesis - Signal Encoding For Spiking Neural Networks
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Spiking neural networks (SNNs) are increasingly popular in the field of artificial intelligence due to their ability to solve complex problems with better processing performance than classical networks while being power efficient since spikes are only exchanged when information is processed. They do so by communicating information through sequences of spikes, thus closely resembling biological neural networks. In order to use spiking neural networks in applications, one must encode numerical data into spikes that are appropriate to supply as input to the network. How to encode appropriately input data (numerical or categorical) into discrete spike events cannot be uniformly answered and remains currently an open question. Furthermore, the choice of the encoding scheme can affect the performance, in terms of accuracy as well as volume and rate which data can be processed, and consequently the energy efficiency of the system.

What you will do

This thesis is divided into several steps and goals: to survey the literature, study several signal encoding approaches and evaluate them in at least one time-series downstream task. The following steps are envisioned as part of the thesis work:

Survey the theoretical foundations as well as applications of the encoding schemes of spiking signal encoding and give an overview over different application-oriented implementations which utilize the schemes.
Demonstrate how these different encoding methods perform on the agreed downstream tasks of spiking neural networks in terms of performance, rate and volume of processing, as well as energy efficiency.

The thesis will be concluded with a report and presentation of the results at Ericsson Research.

Headline: Thesis Project: 30 hp - Steering system modal analysis
Subject: Mechanical engineering
Description:
The department for vehicle dynamics announces a thesis project suitable for two master students. One sub project with experimental focus and one with theoretical focus. A close cooperation between the two projects is beneficial.

Background
The steering system of a commercial vehicle is complex as it is connected to several independently moving components; cab, frame and front axle. The steering system has a direct contact to the driver through his hands and vibrations of various kinds exist and are potentially disturbing. There are many vibration sources in the vehicle, to name a few:
• engine vibrations
• wheel unbalance and radial runout
• brake vibrations
• road disturbances
• steering pump pulsations
• shimmy vibrations
• relative motions between cab, frame and front axle

Project goal
The aim of the two thesis projects is to map these different transfer paths using modal analysis and increase the understanding of the parameters involved.

Part 1 Experimental modal analysis
Supervision RTCD
A suitable test vehicle is instrumented with accelerometers and angle transducers and excited with suitable vibration sources. Data acquisition and modal analysis is performed using Dewesoft, Simcenter Testlab and in-house Matlab tools.

Part 2 Theoretical modal analysis
Supervision RTCC
The test vehicle in part 1 of the project is modelled using ADAMS and the existing model library. Sub models may need calibration and updates and modal Analysis is performed in the same tool as part 1. Simulations may allow for a wider range of excitations.

Cooperation between the two sub projects
The two sub projects can either be executed as a single project with two candidates writing a single report or as two separate projects with two independent reports. Candidates can apply either individually or as a duo.

Contact person
RTCC, Ted Demner ted.demner@scania.com
RTCD, Jolle Ijkema, jolle.ijkema@scania.com

Headline: Thesis Project-Lane detection for advance driver assistance systems using deep learning with monochrome gray-scale images
Subject: Electrical Engineering
Description:
Background
Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) are one of the key components to build up the level of autonomy of a driving system. They also play a critical role for safety in modern vehicles with highly autonomous level. The key technologies for ADAS system primarily focus on vision based techniques and safe and smart controls to help the driving systems react with the uncertainties while the vehicles are on-road. The skeleton of  an ADAS system is Lane Keep Assist (LKA) system. Basically, a LKA system includes two parts in which the first part is to provide the information of the vehicle within the lane. The second part uses the output from the first part to give safe and correct steering assistance. To get the information of the vehicles’ position in lanes, lane detections are required. Therefore, the big challenge to enhance the autonomy of the ADAS system relies on the technology used to find and model the lane information, where the camera based vision is the popular technique applied for lane detections.
Recently, with the advancements of machine learning techniques, particular deep learning, have been applied in various applications. Here computer vision has been proven to be most beneficial. Lane detections based on camera take also benefit from such development of technology, to reach to a more robust and efficient solution  to detect and model the left and right side lane markings using cameras to help the vehicles keeping in the middle of the lane. By tracking the lanes when the vehicle is moving, the information of the road such as the width and the curvature are extracted as well as the quality of the lane markings. Those parameters are crucially used as inputs in order to align the vehicle inside the lanes and control the steering assistance.
Thesis target
So far, the problem of detecting the lanes from images captured by cameras has received a lot of attention from the research community. Convention works with computer vision have been based on edge detection with thresholding, line recognition, and then lane modelling. However, the edge detection by thresholding the intensity of the pixels is not robust enough to recognize the lane. Usually the criteria to determine whether a pixel belongs to a lane or not depends not only on the local intensity of the pixel but also its neighbour and the global context of the whole image. Recently, more and more research on lane detection has focused on deep learning to utilize more compact and hierarchical features for the detection tasks. Therefore, the main aim of this thesis work is to investigate the current lane detection with deep learning and propose an efficient approach for lane detection using only monochrome cameras.
Besides, many datasets for the lane detection problem with either normal RGB camera or monochrome cameras have been collected and developed. Therefore, the goal of this thesis is to use publicly available datasets to develop a robust lane detection for a variety of monochrome cameras. To do so, a method to generate synthetic data is needed to convert from RGB to monochrome images or from monochrome to other types of monochrome formats that are used as the input for ADAS functions. Meanwhile, augmentation is also important to ensure a robust solution for camera parameters like distortion, brightness, contrast, etc.
Education
M.Sc. candidates within relevant to the topic should have qualification as following:
Have knowledge on path/motion planning and control
Have knowledge on machine learning and computer vision.
Have knowledge on using Python
Have knowledge on using Matlab and Simulink tools
Have knowledge on image processing
 Number of students: 1 or 2
 Start date: January 2023
 Estimated time: 20 weeks
Contact person
Dr. Lan Anh Trinh, email: lan.anh.trinh@scania.com, phone: +46767211901

Headline: Thesis Project 30 credits - Aerodynamics simulations of Scania trucks using OpenFOAM
Subject: Mechanical engineering
Description:
Background
With the increasing pressure on the automotive industry to minimize energy consumption of vehicle to lower operational costs and comply with environmental restrictions, reduced aerodynamic drag is paramount.

SCANIA, as a premium brand, uses extensively CFD to optimise and improve the aerodynamic properties of vehicles, and takes pride in delivering among the most aerodynamic trucks. As the use of CFD becomes more mature, the accuracy of the results is increasingly demanded. In addition, the complexity and size of the models are increasing, and the investigation of a rising number of configurations is requested. In order to ensure and maintain good quality results, a constant updating and review of the current process and methodology is required while other alternative approaches must be explored.

Objective
Currently, all aerodynamic simulations are time-dependent (using PowerFLOW), which is considered to best describe real-world conditions, but are expensive in both computational time and licensing cost. At the same time, steady state simulations (RANS) are the common methods for aerodynamic simulations in the automotive industry and are usually not so burdensome. It is therefore interesting to investigate the possibilities and limitations that the application of this method may entail. At SCANIA and within the Volkswagen group, OpenFOAM is already used for steady state and transient simulations in other disciplines, mainly due to its short lead time and price, which makes this program a suitable candidate for such an investigation.

Description of work
The final objective is to set up and evaluate a simulation template adapted to truck simulations, and can be based on previous studies with existing models. Among the key areas to investigate:

Adjustment to truck simulation
The template to start from is used for passenger car and will request modification to fulfil the requirements for trucks simulation

Turbulence model and wall function
Investigation of recommended and alternative model stated by the previous studies

Comparison with transient solutions
Difference in absolute values and deviations in the flow field when compared to PowerFLOW

Suitable background
Final year M.Sc. student with background in fluid dynamics and an interest in CFD simulation and vehicle aerodynamics. Experience in CFD simulations will be considered favourably.

Number of students: 1

Start date: 30th January 2023
Estimated time needed: 20 weeks

Contact
Supervisor: Thibaut Bourbon, 08 553 705 03, thibaut.bourbon@scania.com
Group Manager: Martin Jansson, 08 553 894 37, martin.jansson@scania.com

Application
Enclose CV, personal letter and school grades.

Headline: Examensarbete, 30 hp: Schemaläggning av stora multiprocessorsystem genom optimering
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Utforska effektiva metoder för statisk schemaläggning av den typ av stora multiprocessorsystem som finns i moderna flygplan.

Din framtida utmaning
Bakgrund
I dagens flygplan sitter en mängd datorer, sammanbundna via ett kommunikationsnätverk, och inkopplade mot sensorer och ställdon. Detta system, kallat flygplanets avioniksystem, har ansvar för en rad kritiska funktioner såsom styrning, navigering och kommunikation; att det fungerar korrekt är av största vikt. Genom att på förhand schemalägga aktiviteterna i systemets datorer kan man göra det enklare att garantera systemets prestanda och funktion. Men avioniksystemen har blivit mer och mer komplexa, och problemet att schemalägga aktiviteterna i systemet på ett sätt som effektivt utnyttjar systemets resurser har därmed blivit allt mer utmanande. För oss på Saab är det därför av intresse att utforska metoder som kan hantera schemaläggningsproblemet för stora system.

Beskrivning av examensarbetet
I det här exjobbet vill vi undersöka en modern metod från området optimering. Arbetet kommer bestå både i att titta på hur metoden kan tillämpas för att lösa vårat schemaläggningsproblem, att implementera lösningen i något programmerinsspråk, och att utvärdera hur implementationen presterar på indata som är relevant för oss. Vårat förslag är att studera en metod som utnyttjar beslutsdiagram (decision diagrams). Metoder av den här typen har under senare år visat sig fungera bra för schemaläggningsproblem som liknar vårat, och vi är mycket intresserade av möjligheten att ta fram en metod som också fungerar bra för vårat. Har du en stark önskan om att titta på en annan typ av metod kan vi diskutera det.

Den du är idag
Vi söker dig med intresse för optimering och schemaläggning. Du studerar till civilingenjör eller master och ska påbörja examensarbetet under 2022. Du behöver ha kunskaper inom optimering i nivå med en grundläggande kurs på universitetsnivå. Viss färdighet inom programmering behövs också. Ytterligare kunskap eller erfarenhet inom optimering/algoritmer är meriterande.

Befattningen kräver att du genomgår och godkänns enligt vid var tid gällande bestämmelser för säkerhetsskydd. För befattningar där Saab har krav på säkerhetsklassinplacering kan, i förekommande fall, medföra krav på visst medborgarskap.

Vad du blir en del av
På Saab blickar vi ständigt framåt och utmanar gränserna för vad som är tekniskt möjligt. Vi samarbetar med kollegor runt om i världen som alla delar vår utmaning – att göra världen till en säkrare plats. Läs mer om oss här.

Aeronautics, ett affärsområde inom Saab, erbjuder flygrelaterade delsystem, obemannade flygsystem, flygplansstruktur och service till försvarskunder och civil flygindustri över hela världen. Aeronautics ansvarar också för utveckling, produktion, marknadsföring, försäljning och support av Gripensystemet.

Sista ansökningsdag
2022-11-30

Vänligen observera att vi arbetar med löpande urval och tjänsten kan komma att tillsättas innan sista ansökningsdatum har gått ut.

Saab är ett företag där människan står i centrum. Vi har en god arbetsmiljö där vi stöttar och hjälper varandra att göra vårt bästa. Kontinuerligt lärande, välmående, karriär- och talangutveckling är exempel på områden där vi alltid arbetar hårt för att säkerställa att du som medarbetare får de möjligheter som du behöver.

Headline: Master Thesis in Sustainable Business Models
Subject: Sustainability
Description:
We are looking for Master Thesis students who want to do research in the area of Sustainable Business models within the Manufacturing industry. You probably have an interest in both the business side as well as the operational side of a company, including Product Lifecycle Management, Servitization and Data Management.

Master thesis approach
We encourage you to bring your own ideas and subject for Master Thesis and we develop the scope together. The most optimal setup would be if you are two students performing the master thesis together since this will improve the quality of work and positively impact your experience of the whole project.

Here's how you can contribute
The Master thesis will contribute to the business development of NewCore and our Clients. Hence, we expect you to have an ability to build relationships both internally and externally. It's important that you are highly motivated and have high level of self-leadership and time management.

A few fun facts
It goes without saying that every team member is extremely important to us - and so are you! You will be part of our fantastic team and invited to join our weekly team meetings. After finalizing the thesis, we want you to present the results to the whole team.

We are located in Stockholm but the Master Thesis can be performed from anywhere in the world.

The Master Thesis will be conducted over a 20-week period. We offer 1000 SEK per hp/credit per Master Thesis.

Headline: Master Thesis - AI-Enabled Cloud RAN Test Automation
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
About this opportunity

The introduction of 5G New Radio has made the RAN more complex by increasing the number of band combinations that have to be managed and extending the capability of the network to support multiple network slices with different characteristics. At the same time, the high degree of agility and flexibility that cloud-native RAN implementations demand makes manual intervention virtually impossible. To operate efficiently, a network at this level of complexity requires RAN automation.

What you will do

This thesis aims to focus on a data-driven approach to Cloud RAN test automation. By leveraging the natural complexity between functionality in the Cloud RAN domain using artificial intelligence (AI) can help us for Cloud RAN test automation. Advantages commonly attributed to automation include higher production rates and increased productivity, more efficient use of materials, better product quality, improved safety, shorter workweeks, and reduced lead times. In automated testing, with AI and ML, machines can write flawless codes themselves, which can directly impact both quality and the delivery time of the Cloud Ran applications. The input for test automation, is a set of manual test specification written in natural texts, where the expected output is automated test scripts.

You will bring

This project aims at a group of 2 students in computer science, computer engineering, AI/machine learning or similar.

Headline: Examensarbete programvaruutveckling våren 2023, Skovik
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Ska du göra ditt exjobb i vår? Gör ditt exjobb hos Skovik.

1. Kryptografiska garantier i mjukvaruleveranskedjan
De senaste åren har flera uppmärksammade intrång skett via mjukvaruleveranskedjan, ex. attacken på SolarWinds i USA. Genom att använda kryptografisk signering av kodändringar och byggda artefakter kan man motverka vissa typer av angrepp. Undersök vilka mekanismer som kan användas och implementera detta i ett led i leveranskedjan.

2. Typning i dynamiskt typade språk
Flera dynamiskt typade språk har introducerat metoder för att statiskt definiera typer, och därmed hitta fel innan körning med hjälp av statisk analys. Exempelvis TypeScript för JS, mypy i Python samt Sorbet för Ruby.

Ett exjobb kan utforska vanliga fel som görs i typade miljöer och om, samt hur, nyss nämnda verktyg kan förebygga eller upptäcka dessa fel. Även en fallstudie på kodbaser skulle kunna passa inom detta område.

3. WASM och embedded runtimes
WASM är ett nytt öppet och portabelt binärformat, med vilket man kan skapa säkra sandlådor [sandboxes] för exekvering av opålitlig kod i ett värdsystem. Utvärdera omfattningen av abstraktionskostnaden som sandlådan medför och jämför med andra isoleringstekniker.

4. Mätdata från kortlivade containrar
Containrar lever ibland väldigt kort, kanske bara några sekunder, vilket ställer nya krav på loggdata och systeminformation (CPU, minnesanvändning, etc). Titta på vilka nya problem som containrar introducerar och hur dessa kan lösas.

5. [en idé vi kommer på tillsammans]
Vi diskuterar tillsammans fram ett uppsatsämne. Alla områden inom datorteknik fungerar. Vi letar framförallt efter rätt personer att göra sitt exjobb hos oss.

## ERSÄTTNING
70 000 SEK

## OM FÖRETAGET
Skovik är ett system som automatiserar hanteringen av kvitton på företag. Produkten används av Klarna, Netlight, Kry, Fyndiq, Volvo Car Mobility, Tink, AddQ och drygt tusen andra företag. Kontoret ligger på Engelbrektsgatan 7, intill Humlegården.

https://skovik.com/sv/

## MÅLGRUPP
Platsern riktar sig till studenter på utbildningen Datateknik. Vi tar ibland in från andra program, men det förutsätter goda programmeringskunskaper. Gäller 30p eller 15p exjobb.

## FÖRKUNSKAPER
Exjobbet kräver inte att man har läst en viss inriktning eller specifika kurser.

## FRAMTIDEN
Om exjobbet går bra, du trivs på företaget och vi känner att du passar in i teamet finns goda möjligheter till anställning. Flera som tidigare gjort sitt exjobb hos oss arbetar på företaget idag och vi tar aldrig in fler studenter än vi har heltidstjänster att erbjuda vid exjobbets slut.

## KONTAKTUPPGIFTER
Maila alexander@skovik.com om du undrar någonting innan din ansökan, alternativt vill diskutera upplägg eller idéer för ett exjobb.

## ANSÖKAN
Skicka antingen ett mail till alexander@skovik.com eller använd formuläret nedanför.
Ansökningar behandlas löpande, så ansök idag om du är intresserad.

Headline: MSc thesis - Reinforcement learning policies for energy-aware mobile networks
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering

Headline: Master Thesis: Trailer Dynamics Model for Autonomous Vehicle Motion on Low Friction Surfaces
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Background

The increased demand for transportation lead to increased interest in autonomous vehicles (AVs). AVs are already a reality, however they still have some limitations. AVs have the potential to improve productivity, decrease traffic congestions, decrease the number of accidents, decrease the air pollution as well as decrease the energy consumption.

Current AVs are able to perform well under nominal conditions. However, testing AVs in low friction scenarios poses a significant risk.  Testing in a simulation environment (Software-In-Loop) has emerged as a climate friendly way to test automotive software in fast iterations. In order for the simulation environment to be reliable and close enough to real life vehicles, the simulation model has to appropriately capture the elements of vehicle motion on different road conditions. Having a simulation depicting truck and trailer in different road conditions plays a key role in Scania’s autonomous solution to be able to be operational in all weather conditions.


Master Thesis Description

In this thesis, you will explore a few truck and trailer models, comparing the complexity and scalability trade-off between them. A highly detailed simulation model of a truck and trailer will capture all aspects of road vehicle dynamics. However, such a model could be hard to maintain and needs to be adapted to parameter changes. Finding a balance between the two is key.

The project is a part of the AllDrive project in Scania Autonomous Transport Solutions to target autonomous road driving in all weather conditions. The project will be conducted at Scania with periodic follow up meetings with all supervisors. Furthermore, all implementation will be done in Scania’s autonomous vehicle system and software stack. Constant support and help will be provided from engineering experts and PhD students.

Deliverables

Literature review;

Investigate different models

Implement the model in simulation

Validate model with measured data or high-fidelity simulation model

Investigate vehicle configuration sensitivity

Investigate road friction sensitivity

Compare model scalability and complexity

Determine suitable test scenarios to induce unstable vehicle behaviour


Qualifications

Master student with a background in vehicle dynamics. Knowledge in control theory and system identification is meritorious.

Knowledge of Matlab is needed. C++ and IPG-TruckMaker knowledge will be valued.

Details

Thesis completion credits: 30hp

Start date for the project: January 2023 or according to agreement

Estimated duration: 20 weeks

Contact

Ankur Fartyal – Development engineer, Autonomous Motion Control at Scania, ankur.fartyal@scania.com

Pedro Lima – Senior development engineer, Autonomous Motion Control at Scania, pedro.lima@scania.com

Daniel Fellke – Group manager at Scania, daniel.fellke@scania.com

Application

Application should include a CV and a certificate of studies, including courses attended and obtained grades.

Headline: Wireless channel estimation and prediction for drones using Mathematica
Location: KTH EECS Division of Decision and Control
Subject: Electrical Engineering
Description:
6G cellular networks will control uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAV), also called drones. The wireless channel between drones and terrestrial access points typically undergoes fast fading and is difficult to estimate and predict due to a phenomenon called channel aging. Channel aging refers to fast changes in the channel due to high mobility and other factors.

In this master thesis, we will build  a mathematical model for aging wireless channels and test methods to estimate and predict its characteristics using Mathematica. The key idea is to model the wireless channel as an autoregressive  stochastic process that can be observed (measured) with certain frequency. Observations improve the channel estimation but cost valuable wireless resources, which makes it non-trivial how often such measurements should be made.

This project work requires interest in probability theory, statistics and programming skills in Mathematica. The project will be supervised by adjunct prof. Gabor Fodor at KTH EECS, also affiliated with Ericsson Research. The project work will build heavily on the material available at https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.00213, which provides a theoretical foundation for the project. The master thesis will verify the models proposed in that paper and extend them for other wireless channel models, which are not studied in that paper. If successful, the project should contribute to the currently ongoing 6G SKY project, which studies air space coverage solutions in future 6G cellular networks.

Headline: Combining Digital Signatures and Ledger Technology
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Background

With the over-hype of blockchain being passed us, people are starting to find real application of ledger technology. A couple of such examples in the cyber security area are Certificate Transparency, SSI (Self-Sovereign Identities) and Sigstore.

Sigstore is a good example of combining digital signatures, for code signing, and ledger technology, for an easy to verify transparency log.

Theory

Document signing is a back-bone technology for the digital society. There are many digital signatures companies and technologies deployed and in use. The easiest to use are typically using low security, while the ones with higher security are harder to use, for example eIDAS Qualified Signatures.

With good example of combination of digital signature and ledger technologies. Are there other good use cases for this technology? For example, can we use the combination for easier to use, or easier to verify document signatures?

Research Question

Investigate the market of digital signature solutions, what different types of technologies are being use, and in some cases mandated?

Can we combine digital signatures with ledger technology in a way to make digital signatures more secure, yet easy to apply and verify?

Implementation

A prototype implementation can be developed using for example SignServer for digital signatures together with Trillian as a ledger.

Reading

https://www.sigstore.dev/
https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/policies/eidas-regulation
https://transparency.dev/
https://www.signserver.org/

Location

The thesis will be conducted at or Solna office not far from Solna Centrum, we have a hyrbrid office solution.

Contact

Dejan Bucar, Software Engineering Manager
dejan.bucar@keyfactor.com
+46(0)709 714 280
https://www.keyfactor.com/

Headline: Migrating to Post Quantum Cryptography
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Background

The move to Post Quantum Cryptography is set to be the biggest change in the cryptography and digital signature industry in decades.
NIST has recently finished it's third round in the post quantum cryptography competition. Related to PKI and digital signatures there are several new algorithms proposed, and along with these new algorithms several suggestions how to migrate existing protocols and solutions into using the new cryptographic algorithms. Considering the vast ecosystem of solutions out there using cryptography this is a daunting task.

Theory

There are currently three digital signature algorithms suggested for standardization. This part of standardization is well covered by NIST, ENISA and similar agencies. The migration path however has the industry scratching their heads to come up with new solution. You want to have different ways for different use cases, but not too many as that will fraction an already resource constrained industry too much, wasting money and resources. We are particularly interested in the way PKI migration will happen, which is the infrastructure underlying all secure communication such as TLS.

Some existing suggested methods related to PKI are:

* Add a new certificate authority hierarchy based on only a single post quantum algorithm, migrating to using the new certificates as applications support them.
* Add a new certificate authority hierarchies based on composite certificates, certificates with both a classic algorithm and a post quantum algorithm, and dual signatures. This allows the same certificates to be used in a migration phase, but also requires applications to understand the new composite structures.
* Add a new certificate authority hierarchy based on only a single post quantum algorithm, adding links between old certificates with classic algorithms and new using post quantum algorithms. This binds two certificates together and applications can choose one or the other, or both, to use in a protocol exchange.
* The methods solve the same underlying problem, but in different technical ways.

Research Question

* An open question that has not been answered is how the different methods of cryptography migration affects systems.
* What are the characteristics of the different migration methods?
* What changes are needed to relying applications in order to support one or the other of the proposed methods?
* What are the implementation burdens on developers of the PKI?
* What are the implementation burdens on developers of relying on applications?
* Answering these questions can help the ecosystem select the best, or the best ones, of the alternatives currently suggested.

Implementation

Once figured out, one selected method could be implemented in a CA tooling system to issue the required certificates, and a sample application can be modified to make use of them.

Reading

https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/nistir/8413/final
https://datatracker.ietf.org/wg/lamps/about/
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ounsworth-pq-composite-sigs/
https://trac.ietf.org/trac/sec/wiki/PQCAgility

Location

The thesis will be conducted at or Solna office not far from Solna Centrum, we have a hyrbrid office solution.

Contact

Dejan Bucar, Software Engineering Manager
dejan.bucar@keyfactor.com
+46(0)709 714 280
https://www.keyfactor.com/

Headline: Safe usage of Stateful Hash Based Signature Algorithms
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Background

The move to Post Quantum Cryptography is set to be the biggest change in the cryptography and digital signature industry in decades.

Before the final standardization taking place by NIST, NIST has named two stateful hash-based signature algorithms to be secure against the quantum computer threat. LMS and XMSS are specified in SP 800-208, and RFCs for their usage in internet protocols exists. The downside of using stateful algorithms is the complicated use, which is pointed out by NIST in it's report on the third round of standardization. Basically, the private signature key consists of a tree of keys, and re-using one of the for two signatures breaks the whole security if the system.

There is significant interest in using algorithms from SP 800-208, if we can find a good way to ensure that private keys are never re-used.

Theory

There are some private ideas how the usage of LMS and XMSS keys can be used to issue certificates and sign document and code. The idea is basically to use some randomness features of the keys so that re-use of signature keys can be detected before a signed certificate or document is returned to the requestor. In that case, the re-use of the signature key is never revealed to the outside world, and it can be regarded as safe.

Research Question

Finding a way to safely use LMS and XMSS would enable organizations today looking to implement for example quantum secure code signing to do so. While ideas how to do it exists, it has not been specified anywhere, and not tested.
• Specify how to ensure dual usage of an LMS or XMSS key can be detected for:
• Certificate issuance
• CRL issuance
• Document signatures

Implementation

Once figured out, the safe way to create document signatures can be demonstrated by implementing a prototype using the open-source software SignServer.

Reading

https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/sp/800-208/final
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8708

Location

The thesis will be conducted at or Solna office not far from Solna Centrum, we have a hyrbrid office solution.

Contact

Dejan Bucar, Software Engineering Manager
dejan.bucar@keyfactor.com
+46(0)709 714 280
https://www.keyfactor.com/

Headline: Multiagent Reinforcement Learning for meeting performance objectives for IT services
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
In order to continuously meet performance objectives for an IT service, such as bounds on delays or throughput for service requests, the management system dynamically performs control actions that re-allocate the resources of the IT infrastructure. We apply reinforcement learning (RL) techniques to train agents that periodically performs control actions to allocate resources. A performance objective in this framework is expressed through the reward function in the RL model. We develop the solution using a laboratory testbed that runs the Istio and Kubernetes platforms. As training an RL agent in an operational environment is generally not feasible due to the long training time, we compute the control policies in a simulator, which speeds up the learning process by orders of magnitude. In this approach, the RL system model is learned from testbed measurements; it is then used to instantiate the simulator, which produces near-optimal control policies for various management objectives.

In this project, various multiagent designs for resource will be studied and compared. The main objective is to shorten the training time compared with a single agent, through reducing the action space and exploiting parallelism. Using traces from the laboratory testbed, the student will compute a system model for the RL framework and compute near-optimal control policies for a multiagent control system. The policies will be evaluated in different scenarios.

Prerequisites:

- knowledge in statistics and machine learning
- programming experience in Python
- knowledge in computing systems and networking

Project tasks:

- Perform a background study on multiagent reinforcement learning [1].
- Study the KTH testbed setup and previously conducted experiments [2].
- Using traces from the testbed, train a regressor to obtain an RL system model.
- For a given set of performance objectives train an RL agent on a simulator and evaluate the control policies on the simulator.
- Study options for a multiagent RL design for the same scenario. Implement an RL
algorithm for the simulator.
- Evaluate and compare the performance of several multiagent RL designs on the simulator for a given scenario.
- Optional: Evaluate the obtained control policies on the testbed for the same scenario.

Supervisor: Forough Shahab, EECS/NSE
Examiner: Prof. Rolf Stadler, EECS/NSE

References:
1] D. Bertsekas, Rollout, policy iteration, and distributed reinforcement learning. Athena Scientific, 2021.
[2] F. S. Samani and R. Stadler, “Dynamically meeting performance objectives for multiple services on a service mesh,” in IEEE 18th International Conference on Network and Service Management (CNSM 2022), CNSM 2022, 2022.

Headline: Intrusion detection using hidden Markov models
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
We consider an intrusion prevention use case which involves the IT infrastructure of an organization. The infrastructure includes a set of servers that run client applications and an Intrusion Detection System (IDS), which logs events in real-time. Clients access the applications through a public gateway, which also is open to an attacker. The attacker intrudes on the infrastructure and compromises a set of its servers. The defender continuously monitors the infrastructure through accessing IDS and other statistics.

In this project, you study and evaluate intrusion detection methods of the defender. The methods are based on Hidden Markov Models (HMM) and related techniques. They allow a defender to train models based on observations offline and to predict a sequence of observation statistics online. The predictions allow a defender to estimate whether an attack is occurring and in which attack stage it is. An important part of the project is the experimental evaluation of the studied methods based on measurement traces from a KTH testbed and other published data sets. For the project, you will use the Anaconda environment (anaconda.com), including Jupyter notebook, and the scikit-learn machine learning packages (scikit-learn.org).

Prerequsites:
- good knowledge in statistics, applied probability, and machine learning
- programming experience in Python
- basic knowledge in computing systems and networking

Project tasks:

- Perform a background study on hidden Markov models [?].
- Study the KTH testbed setup and previously conducted experiments [1].
- Model attacker states and corresponding observations applying the HMM framework. Start with a simple attacker model and progress to more complex ones.
- Using traces from the testbed, train HMM configurations, evaluate and compare them for a given set of performance objectives. Draw conclusions about the suitability of the investigated models and algorithms for intrusion detection.
- Use the same models and perform the same evaluation for a different public data set. Compare the results.
- Optional: Design and run your own attacker scenarios on the KTH testbed. Collect traces, train and evaluate predictive models for evolving attacks.
- The above task list can be adapted during the project based on your progress and interest.

Supervisor: Xiaoxuan Wang, EECS/NSE
Examiner: Prof. Rolf Stadler, EECS/NSE
Location: Division Network and Systems Engineering (NSE)

References
[1] K. Hammar and R. Stadler, “Intrusion prevention through optimal stopping,” arXiv preprint arXiv:2111.00289, 2021.

Headline: Logistics study for Husmuttern factory-in-a-box solution for post-war recovery (e.g. Syria, Yemen, Ukraine)
Location: Eskilstuna, RISE office in Mölndal and/or Chalmers
Subject: Sustainability
Description:
Thesis work – Logistics study for Husmuttern factory-in-a-box solution for post-war recovery (e.g. Syria, Yemen, Ukraine) (thesis work can be done in English or Swedish depending on University demand)

Background
For areas in the world that have suffered from war, natural disasters or crisis, there is often a need to get production and construction going in order to build up the civil society. There is need for buildings, healthcare materials and equipment etc. The production and construction capabilities can be limited by local supplies of raw materials and tools as well as by production skills of the local work force.
Husmuttern (husmuttern.se) has built up a concept for building standardized house modules with a production set-up that is not dependent on language and that can have a productive use also by non-experienced personnel. The current supply chain set-up for the house module production is based on a Swedish context. Now they wish to elaborate if the system could be set-up in a foreign context with new local supply chain and different working culture.
The production and supply chain activities contribute to sustainable development with both positive and negative impact, the aim is to maximize positive impact on society while minimizing e.g. negative environmental impact from waste and emissions. However, recent shortages of material have put a pressure on companies to find alternative circular solutions. To address this a sustainability-driven management approach can be implemented. Life cycle management (LCM) is a concept for integrating environmental work into the organizational processes by integrating environmental thinking in every step in the life-cycle.
Goals of the Master’s Thesis
The aim of this master and/or bachelor thesis is to conduct a supply chain analysis and re-design of the factory-in-a-box solution for a foreign location. There may be more than one thesis groups working in different scenarios (e.g. conceptualizing for different countries). Depending on local market context and material availability different re-designs of the product, changes of materials and components, and provide suggestions on how the company can leverage this analysis in its supply chain and with its clients. The students will work independently but with close contact to Husmuttern and RISE.

The students are expected to:
• investigate the availability of raw materials and components in the selected country
• investigate the needs of products and their design for the intended market.
• identify challenges and opportunities
• Assess sustainability of the supply chain
• Suggest different strategic development paths for the conceptual offering.
Expected outcomes
The master’s thesis is expected to generate an understanding of how a logistics and supply chain analysis is carried out taking the local market into account and how this can be leveraged by companies in the supply chain. The gained understanding will be incorporated also in the RESPIRE project to support a move towards a resilient industrial system.
Requirements and the application process
• It is preferred that students write the master’s thesis in pair
• Geographical location: Eskilstuna, RISE office in Mölndal and/or Chalmers TMEor KTH Södertälje
• Applications must be sent latest on November 15th, 2022

Headline: Master thesis: Intracardiac pressure gradients from medical images - fluid mechanics in clinical practice
Subject: Engineering physics
Description:
BACKGROUND
Regional quantification of cardiovascular pressure gradients is critical for diagnosis, treatment planning, and risk prediction of many cardiovascular disease. Still, for a large number of conditions, non-invasive assessment is obstructed by inherent method limitations, and a wide range of clinical instances exist where regional pressure behaviour remains unexplored. To tackle this, we have recently deployed a combination of physics-informed image analysis (invoking fundamental fluid mechanical description of blood flow) and full-field flow imaging (4D Flow MRI) to allow for arbitrary probing of pressure gradients across previously inaccessible compartments.

SCOPE
The purpose of this thesis project is to implement a set of higher-order methods for intracardiac pressure mapping; all developed within our group at KI. Work will include implementation and validation in a simulated image setting, before being tested on clinical image data acquired together with our clinical partners. The work is highly interdisciplinary and involves image acquisition, analysis, fluid mechanical concepts, as well as cardiovascular care exposure.

IMPACT AND NEXT STEPS
Intracardiac pressure gradients have important clinical implications and are already utilized in clinical practice. This project opens assessment across a more comprehensive set of cardiac disorders, exploring fundamental hemodynamic behaviour in coupling to onset of disease. The thesis project has the potential of rendering scientific publication(s) in the field of advanced imaging.

DURATION
The thesis work is planned to start in January 2023, lasting 20 weeks as per agreed with your university supervisor (equivalent of 30 ECTS).

APPLICATION AND REQUIREMENTS
We are looking for ambitious students in data science, machine learning, fluid mechanics, or engineering physics, with the desire to develop data-driven tools to directly change clinical practice. You must have experience in programming (Matlab/Python/unix). Machine learning implementations using Tensorflow is  preferable. Please send your CV and transcript of records to david.marlevi@ki.se.

ABOUT US
The project is based within the research group of clinical physiology and cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging at Karolinska Institutet, where integrated translational imaging research is performed together with engineering scientists, medical physicists, and clinical fellows. The work will be directly tied to the clinical line of work at the unit of clinical physiology at Karolinska University Hospital. The primary supervisor is a scientific lead in quantitative image analysis, having recently ported work on 4D Flow imaging from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) back to Sweden and Karolinska. If of interest to the student, the project may be performed in direct collaboration with international partners (King’s College London, University of Michigan, etc.) where past work on super-resolution work has been performed.

REFERENCES
1. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1361841520303121
2. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-37714-0

Headline: Master thesis: Physics-informed deep learning for next-generation medical imaging – super-resolution 4D Flow MRI
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
BACKGROUND
Medical imaging has come to revolutionize the way we diagnose, monitor, and treat disease. This is particularly true in the field of cardiovascular care, where a range of imaging modalities are used to interrogate anatomy and function using non-invasive means. However, a range of clinical challenges remain where available image techniques are hindered by inherent method limitations (restricted resolution; excessive noise; etc.). The incorporation of machine learning techniques and data-driven algorithms into clinical image research is however starting to fundamentally change what can be analysed, and resolved, opening for individualized patient-care and directly improved clinical risk stratification.

SCOPE
The purpose of this thesis project is to implement and explore super-resolution neural networks to enhance the spatiotemporal resolution of 4D Flow magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) – a novel imaging technique enabling imaging of 3D blood flow across the entire cardiovascular system. Work will start with simulated image sets, allowing for controlled implementation and testing of various super-resolution networks. Depending on the desire of the student, work can also include exploration of so called physics-informed variations (where incorporation of fundamental physical laws help improve network predictions). Being based within the cardiovascular magnetic resonance group at Karolinska Institutet, the work will also include acquisition of clinical image data, with both validation and testing expected in a direct clinical setting on patients with disease types relevant for super-resolution flow imaging.

IMPACT AND NEXT STEPS
Super-resolution 4D Flow MRI has the ability to fundamentally change the way we interrogate advanced hemodynamic behaviour, opening up for exploration of complex flows across the heart, aorta, and brain. Once implemented, the thesis project has the potential of rendering scientific publication(s) in the field of advanced imaging, as well as expand into potential doctoral thesis work in translational imaging science at Karolinska Instiutet.

DURATION
The thesis work is planned to start in January 2023, lasting 20 weeks as per agreed with your university supervisor (equivalent of 30 ECTS).

APPLICATION AND REQUIREMENTS
We are looking for ambitious students in data science, machine learning, fluid mechanics, or engineering physics, with the desire to develop data-driven tools to directly change clinical practice. You must have experience in programming and machine learning implementations, preferable using Python (Tensorflow; see reference work: https://github.com/EdwardFerdian/4DFlowNet). Please send your CV and transcript of records to david.marlevi@ki.se.

ABOUT US
The project is based within the research group of clinical physiology and cardiovascular magnetic resonance imaging at Karolinska Institutet, where integrated translational imaging research is performed together with engineering scientists, medical physicists, and clinical fellows. The work will be directly tied to the clinical line of work at the unit of clinical physiology at Karolinska University Hospital. The primary supervisor is a scientific lead in quantitative image analysis, having recently ported work on 4D Flow imaging from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) back to Sweden and Karolinska. If of interest to the student, the project may be performed in direct collaboration with international partners (King’s College London, University of Michigan, etc.) where past work on super-resolution work has been performed.

REFERENCES
1. https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fphy.2020.00138/full
2. https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.08.25.457611v1.abstract
3. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0169260720315625?casa_token=0Ev14OTSoDcAAAAA:fpRrPTewMIMkuJUlQ5zrSxDWpKZ-UaAZQQf5_BDAMwTBY_6Q3uqNHcMa-3TbVktJP62zDgq4
