Headline: EMI immune probe design exploration and implementation
Subject: Engineering
Description:
Background
Leading societies to a low carbon future, Alstom develops and markets mobility solutions that provide the sustainable foundations for the future of transportation. Our product portfolio ranges from high-speed trains, metros, monorail, and trams to integrated systems, customised services, infrastructure, signalling and digital mobility solutions. Joining us means joining a caring, responsible, and innovative company where more than 70,000 people lead the way to greener and smarter mobility, worldwide.

Balise is a wireless transponder used as a beacon in many train signal systems in the world, Among them, the European system: ERTMS. This system has been designed for optimal performance and availability.  Balise is exposed to a harsh environment, where there’re different types of debris, e.g. metal objects, iron ore, clear water, salt water. These debris together with temperature cycling would have impact on Balise’s uplink characteristics.
Therefore, during the design and development, the Balise transmission performance needs to be measured and evaluated. However, the traditional measurement tool suffers from lab EM disturbance.

Problem description and goals
The focus of this master thesis is the architecture design and implementation of an EMI immune measurement tool, to measure and characterise the transmission flux of a Balise or Antenna, then transfer the signal via optical fibre to PC for signal processing.

Within the required responsibilities the candidate should:
• Based on system level specifications, establish block level specifications, identify key-problem and propose/analyse different architectures that would meet specifications.
• Based on block level specifications, select and justify the components which will together build up the measurement tool.
• Compare and analyse the measurement result with DSP between the traditional measurement probe and the EM immune measurement probe.

Headline: Extrajobb till kundtjänst
Subject: Electrical Engineering
Description:
Extrajobb till kundtjänst


Vill du ha en spännande och utvecklande tjänst hos oss på Franke?

Är du en social och prestigelös person som trivs med att arbeta i team? Lockas du av att arbeta med kundservice? Har du dessutom kunskaper i finska och/eller annat nordisk språk?

Då bör du extrajobb som kundservicemedarbetare hos oss på Franke.

 Som medarbetare inom vår kundtjänst ingår du i ett nordiskt team. I det här fallet kommer du att utgå från Bromma och även ha möjlighet att arbeta på distans.

 Din huvudsakliga arbetsuppgift kommer att vara orderläggning som utgångspunkt för att sedan kunna utvecklas inom flertalet arbetsuppgifter på kundservice.

Det är ett varierat jobb där du aktivt samarbetar med stora delar av företaget, allt från produktion, lager och marknad. Vi söker dig som har ett intresse av att hjälpa andra som alltid sätter kunden i fokus.

Nordiska teamet är placerat i Danmark. Den här tjänsten är placerad i Bromma som en visstidsanställning.

 Arbetsuppgifter

I rollen som Kundtjänstmedarbetare ger du råd, anvisningar och information om Frankes produktsortiment. Du tar emot och registrerar order, ger information om leveranstider till våra kunder.

Franke ingår i en global koncern där det finns goda möjligheter för dig att utvecklas och lära dig nya saker.

 Om dig

För att trivas i rollen tror vi att du är en serviceinriktad person som gillar att lära dig nya saker och trivs i en administrativ roll.

Du trivs i en roll där du får möjlighet att lära dig nya saker och att supportera både våra externa och interna kunder.

Kvalifikationer

Vi tror att du har:

• Goda kunskaper i Finska, Engelska och ett annat nordiskt språk i tal och skrift.

• God datorvana.

Vi erbjuder dig:

En intressant och utvecklande tjänst hos en unik arbetsgivare med både utveckling och produktion under samma tak.

Varmt välkommen med din ansökan

Om Franke

Franke Futurum AB är Nordens ledande tillverkare av produkter för köksventilation och marknadsledande i Sverige. Huvudkontor och produktion ligger i Byske i Västerbotten. Företaget har en omsättning på 320 miljoner kronor och ca 180 anställda. Franke Futurum ingår i Frankekoncernen.

Franke finns i 40 länder och våra produkter präglas av god design och gedigen kvalitet. I vårt produktsortiment hittar du fläktar, diskbänkar, blandare, avfallssortering, ugnar och hällar.

Headline: Noise characteristics in HD infrared imaging arrays for space applications
Subject: Engineering physics
Description:
Background:

IRnova is a Swedish company engaged in the development, manufacturing and marketing of high-end cooled infrared detectors and related technology.

In ongoing R&D projects at IRnova funded by the European Space Agency (ESA), Type-II superlattice (quantum structure) detector arrays for mid wavelength (MWIR, 3-5 µm) infrared imaging are being developed, focusing on large detector formats (HD = High Definition) with small pixel sizes. The detectors show very good imaging performance, however, we can observe a phenomenon called Random Telegraph Signal (RTS) noise, which appears as blinking pixels in the arrays. The physical origin of the RTS noise is so far not well understood, but could have several origins, such as trapping/de-trapping from defect levels in either the detector material or from surface traps at the interfaces of the detector pixels.  In this master thesis, we intend to study how the pixel size affects the RTS noise and how it is correlated with 1/f noise measured in single pixel photodiodes.

This master thesis work will be focused on four parts:

1) Python programming of a graphical user interface for the noise measurement setup
2) Measurements of the noise in single pixel photodiodes and imaging arrays
3) Analysis of the measured data in terms of underlaying stochastic processes
4) Correlation between RTS noise in imaging arrays and 1/f noise in fabricated photodiodes.

The project will be performed in collaboration with the Department of Electronics, School of EECS at KTH.  Professor Gunnar Malm, who has long experience of electrical characterization of noise and fluctuations in semiconductor devices will act as thesis examiner at KTH. An academic supervisor will also be assigned.

Timeline:

1. Literature study on 1/f-noise and RTS noise in infrared imaging arrays (2 weeks)
2. Getting familiar with the noise measurement setup and programming of graphical interface for the noise measurement setup (in Python, MATLAB, Java, ..) (2 weeks)
3. Study of noise in different T2SL photodiodes and imaging arrays as a function of bias and temperature. (3 weeks)
4. Analysis of the measured data in terms of underlaying stochastic processes (modelling and calculation in Python) (4 weeks)
5. Correlation between RTS noise in imaging arrays and 1/f noise in photodiodes (3 weeks)
6. Writing of Master thesis (6 weeks)

Examiner and advisors at KTH and IRnova:
- Gunnar Malm (Professor, thesis examiner at KTH), gunta@kth.se
- David Ramos (PhD student, IRnova), David.Ramos@ir-nova.se
- Ruslan Ivanov (Research engineer, IRnova), Ruslan.Ivanov@ir-nova.se
- Marie Delmas (Research engineer, IRnova), Marie.Delmas@ir-nova.se
- Linda Höglund (R&D Manager, IRnova), Linda.Hoglund@ir-nova.se

Start: January 2023

End: Preferably not later June 14, 2023

Apply to: Linda.Hoglund@ir-nova.se  by sending your CV (including education, relevant courses, work merits and skills) and a personal letter describing yourself, your interest in this topic and plans for your future career.

Payment: Bonus when the thesis has been defended.

Headline: Master Thesis: Validate and test different control systems for a tribometer at variable speed and load.
Subject: Electrical Engineering
Description:
Take the opportunity to write your master thesis with our engaged team and contribute to our research within future tightening techniques!

Education requirement:
Mechatronics / Electronics Engineering

Target:
Validation and testing of the control system for the Pin-on-Disc tribometer to measure friction in the contact at variable speed and load in a short time interval.

Background:
During tightening of a screw, the variation in friction will affect the force acting on the joint, especially when tightening using torque as a control parameter. Since friction is an important factor when aiming for a specific clamping force, it of interest to simulate the contact and friction in the screw head to joint and thread interfaces. This will lead to a possibility of gaining a deeper knowledge of friction characteristics when tightening and how the dynamic friction relates to different coatings/ materials and screw geometries. In the end, it will enable us to develop tightening strategies that compensate for the friction variation to assure a better quality of the joint understanding friction behaviour will make it possible to influence the quality of the assembly.

Mission:
Design a robust and flexible control system for the Pin-on–Disc machine. Evaluate different controller strategies to obtain the best tracking performance for both the pin and the disc actuation. Evaluating and incorporating different sensors such as acoustic, heat and other sensors relevant to study friction and stick-slip phenomenon.

Your profile
Experience and/or interest in the following:
Mechatronics/ Electronics
Well versed in control theory, MATLAB and Simulink
Relevant knowledge in sensors
Further information

For more information please contact supervisor Mayank Kumar: mayank.x.kumar@atlascopco.com, +46 (0)72 145 9613

Applications will be reviewed continuously.

Interested in being part of our team? Join us on our journey for a better tomorrow.

Headline: Masters Thesis: Determine the clamp force by digital image correlation
Subject: Electrical Engineering
Description:
Take the opportunity to write your master thesis with our engaged team and contribute to our research within future tightening techniques!

Education requirement:
Mechatronic, Electrical, or Data engineering (or similar engineering disciplines)

Background:
Research on methods for determining the elongation or clamp force during tightening has been conducted at Atlas Copco for many years. The reason for this is that today´s tightening control methods rely on torque and angle. A third measure would increase the confidence in the assembly quality. An internal pre-study including an experiment has shown that there is a correlation between clamp force and deformations captured using digital image correlation (DIC).

Target:
Development of a Real-time Digital Image Correlation (DIC) based algorithm that can compensate for the movement of a screwdriver or other noises to estimate the clamp force in the tightened bolt. Clamp force is the force that holds the joint and avoids from apart

Mission:
Develop an algorithm that estimates the clamp force by using the DIC of a joint in real-time in a moving environment. In the end, the algorithm’s output should be a trigger signal to indicate the reached clamp force.

Your profile
Experience and/or interest in the following:
Image processing
Embedded systems
Python
Hands-on experiments
Further information  

For more information please contact supervisor Kajsa Hjort: Kajsa.hjort@atlascopco.com, +4676 719 46 89

Applications will be reviewed continuously.

Interested in being part of our team? Join us on our journey for a better tomorrow.

Headline: Master Thesis: An apparatus to measure frequency response in bolted joints
Subject: Electrical Engineering
Description:
Take the opportunity to write your master thesis with our engaged team and contribute to our research within future tightening techniques!

Education requirement:
Mechanical Engineering/Mechatronics or similar.

Target:
Development, design, manufacture, and verification of an apparatus to measure and correlate frequency response in a threaded fastener joint to the bolt preload/clamp force.

Background:
Research on methods for determining the elongation or clamp force during tightening has been conducted at Atlas Copco for many years. The reason for this is that today´s tightening control methods rely on torque and angle. A third measure would increase confidence in the assembly quality. By measuring the frequency response in the joint one can relate it to clamp force similar to evaluating the pitch when tuning a guitar string.

Mission:
Develop an apparatus which detects and record the frequency response for a specific joint, then relate that to the bolt preload/clamp force measured using a traditional load cell. Should the response be representative for a specific joint type, this apparatus and methodology could be used to control or monitor the development of clamp force in a joint.

Your profile
Experience and/or interest in the following:
•    Mechanical engineering, mechatronics.
•    Interest in sensors.
•    Basic knowledge in programming.

Interested in being part of our team? Join us on our journey for a better tomorrow.

Applications will be reviewed continuously.

Headline: Masters thesis: Reduce vibration in angle tools using electric pulse tightening
Subject: Electrical Engineering
Description:
Take the opportunity to write your master thesis with our engaged team and contribute to our research within future tightening techniques!

Education requirement:
Mechanical Engineering / Product design

Background:
Atlas Copco has recently started to implement and sell a pulsing tightening program called TensorPulse that can be used together with electric angle type tightening tools. It aims to reduce the reaction force that the operator (or co-bot) experiences compared to a continuous tightening strategy, but it usually increases the vibration level. At a high target torque, the vibrations can get too high for long term use of the tool. No solution known to us is available on the market.

Target:
Development, design, manufacturing, and verification of a prototype that reduces the vibrations on the operator when using an electric angle type runner with a pulsing strategy. The task is either to change the design of the tool, the tool handle, or add an accessory handle that dampens the vibrations.

Mission:
The prototype should be aimed to be possible to later implement in a real tool. That means it can’t be too heavy, bulky, nor too high cost.  Acceptable vibration level is approx. 6 m/s2 compared to originally 19 m/s2.

Your profile:
Experience and/or interest in the following:
•    Mechanical product design
•    Dynamic simulation skills are a plus
•    Interest in vibration measurement

Further information
For more information contact supervisor Johan Rönblom: johan.ronblom@atlascopco.com, +46 725249743

Applications will be reviewed continuously.

Interested in being part of our team? Join us on our journey for a better tomorrow.

Headline: Thesis Project: 30 credits – Dynamic axle load estimation for improved control of electrified vehicles
Subject: Mechanical engineering
Description:
Scania is now undergoing a transformation from being a supplier of trucks, buses and engines to a supplier of complete and sustainable transport solutions.

This thesis is a chance to be a part of Scania´s transformation from being a supplier of trucks, buses and engines to a supplier of complete and sustainable transport solutions. If this seems interesting, we want you to be a part of the future!

Background
One of Scania’s key priorities is driving the shift to sustainable transport, which we do through innovation. The control for propulsion and braking is a complex combination regarding stability and energy efficiency. In order to control the vehicle in the optimal way information about the current and future state of the vehicle is a key element.

Description
A truck that accelerates, brakes or uses regenerative braking will have a dynamic load transfer in between the axles. In order to apply a correct amount of torque to the wheels without causing too much tire wear or an instable situation the axle load has to be known during dynamic driving. The complex mechanics and design of a truck with more than two axles makes the estimation of the load transfer a non-trivial problem. The aim of this thesis is to investigate the dynamic behaviour, create a model of the mechanical system and then use the model to estimate the axles loads. In order to do this you will have to both study the problem from a theoretical point of view and by real world testing. This will include preparing tests, testing in truck and analyse the collected data.

Goal
The goal of this thesis is to have a real time estimation of the axle load during dynamic driving. The estimation should be validated on measurement data but also by implementing a software prototype in a vehicle. The thesis can also be extended to several vehicle configurations and tractor with trailer.

Your profile
This thesis is suitable for two students studying M.Sc. in engineering or similar with an interest in mechatronics, physical modelling and signal processing. The student should have some familiarity with coding. Preferred skills in Matlab/Simulink. We expect you to be curious, open minded and likes to take your own initiatives.

Time plan
The project is planned to take 20 weeks with start in January.

Contact person and supervisor
Filip Larsson, Development Engineer, 0855352842, filip.larsson@scania.com
Henrik Johansson, Development Engineer, 0855372037, henrik.x.johansson@scania.com

Application
Your application should contain a covering letter, CV and transcripts.

Selections will be made throughout the application period.

Headline: Thesis Worker - Laser welding of copper
Subject: Vehicle Engineering
Description:
Thesis Worker at Volvo Cars

Welcome to explore the world of Volvo Cars by writing your thesis with us! As a thesis worker in our organization you are supported by a supervisor who follows you during your project. All thesis projects are arranged in business critical areas and therefore you will be able to contribute to our company purpose – providing freedom to move in a safe, sustainable and personal way – from day one!

Background
The Electric Drive department at Volvo Cars is proud of being one of the most successful players in SW development for Electric Vehicles. We are responsible for delivering system solutions and SW functionality for the Inverters, Electric machines, and transmission in our electrified vehicles. Our vision is to become “Leading in electrification” and aiming to contribute to world class sustainability, energy efficiency, E-machine functionality, customer satisfaction, to all our future products.

Scope
Develop a Volvo standard for copper laser welding:
Increasing demand for electric vehicles has put a significant stress on designing highly efficient E-machines. One of our focus areas is the bonding between the copper busbars that connects the electric motor and the inverter and the copper winding to the AC Choke

The main objective with this thesis work is to develop and create a new Volvo standard for laser welding of copper wire.

Activities we foresee that should be done during this thesis work are:
•    Benchmarking of international standards for laser welding of copper.
•    Support in describing quality requirements for welding operation
•    Support in creating technical regulation.
•    Describe verification methods
•    Technical discussions with suppliers of welding equipment
•    Cooperate with Volvo Standard Department to implement a new laser welding of copper standard for Volvo Cars.

Your contribution is our future
We believe that the suitable students study Electric power engineering or Mechanical Engineer.

Duration
• The duration of the Thesis is approx. 4-5 months
• The Thesis starts in spring 2023, exact date to be discussed
• 30 ECTS (academic credits) if in agreement with your Thesis Advisor in University
• This thesis is to be conducted by 2 students working in a pair
• Office, computer, and software will be arranged by University and Volvo Cars.

Be part of the change – apply today!
Selection will be ongoing during the application period, so do not hesitate to send in your application. Attach your resume and cover letter and copies of grades. You can provide a reference if you would like. Please note that due to GDPR, applications by email will not be accepted.

We want your application at the latest 2022-12-02.

If you have any additional questions regarding the position, you are welcome to contact:
Supervisor Roar Matsson at roar.matsson@volvocars.com, (+46729775109).
Hiring manager Martin Randle at martin.randle@volvocars.com, (+46729775319).

We are Volvo Cars
Volvo Cars is a company on a mission to bring traditional car manufacturing into a connected, sustainable and smart future. Since 1927, we've been known for our commitment to safety and for creating innovative cars that make life less complicated. In 2010, we decided to radically redefine our business, resulting in a totally new generation of cars and technology, as well as steady growth and record sales - and we're only getting started. By 2025, we aim to have yearly sales of 1.2 million cars, 50% of which will be electric vehicles and sold directly to customers through digital channels. We also intend to strengthen our position as a modern, progressive employer committed to diversity and gender and racial equality. We believe in the power of people. Join us and be part of Volvo Cars' transformation.

Headline: Data science/mathematics project in matching algorithms
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Help people find their next home!

Qasa is a Schibsted-backed startup that aims to completely reform the housing rental market throughout the world. If you're intrigued by building something with a substantial impact, check us out.

We are looking for a Stockholm-based student interested in doing a bachelor's or master's level degree project in mathematics/data science. Specifically, we want to improve our current matching algorithm. The successful candidate will be invited to spend the Spring semester at our office working closely with the data science, product, and development team.

Qasa AB is an end-to-end transactional marketplace for rentals in Sweden and Finland. In addition to our own brand (qasa.se and qasa.fi), we also power Blocket Bostad through a white-label solution. Qasa started in 2014 and today we are more than 40+ full-time employees.

In Sweden, we are the largest rental marketplace with more than 5+ million home applications made and 100,000+ homes listed each year. One of the biggest and most exciting challenges we face in handling this amount of volume is efficiently connecting tenants with the home just for them. Match-making! And this is where you come in...

Examples of things you’ll work on:
- Research, develop and prototype algorithms/models for matching, e.g., ELO, Gale-Shapely, stable marriage.
- Solve challenging problems in the domain of feature engineering.
- Analyze and improve the efficiency and accuracy of existing ML systems.
- Prototyping, building, and analysis of experimental models.
- Collaboration with and support other members of our product team.
- Communication of research, progress, and results.

You could be a great fit if you enjoy:
- solving analytical problems using quantitative approaches
- working within the fields of machine learning, statistics,
- optimization, computer science, applied mathematics, or data science
- manipulating and analyzing complex, large-scale, high-dimensionality data from varying sources
- applying theoretical and empirical research to solve problems
- communicating complex research in a clear, precise, and actionable manner
- working in Python, Ruby on Rails, PostgreSQL, the AWS ecosystem, or other related programming languages/services
- building systems based on machine learning and/or deep learning methods

Qasa has since it was founded in 2014 strived to create a safe, hassle-free home rental experience for both landlords and tenants. In February 2019, Qasa was acquired by Schibsted and Blocket with an ambition to take Qasa to its full potential through its well-established marketplaces throughout the world.

The journey from a small startup to a full-blown worldwide rental platform starts now. We have massive support from Schibsted and a highly competent team with an almost infinite amount of drive who are committed to building a marketplace that will dominate the market for decades. If it thrills you to have a large impact in a team that builds something that will become something substantial, then you should get in touch and apply to become our newest team member!

Headline: Investigation of increased limits for utilization of SiC MOSFETs
Subject: Electrical Engineering
Description:
Background
The advent of Wide Band Gap power semiconductors, especially Silicon Carbide MOSFETs, has a significant impact in creating more compact, low weight and energy efficient railway electric propulsion systems. One parameter that has not been investigated very deeply is how the theoretically increased Safe Operating Area of these devices relative to their rated current can be used to generate further system level benefits.

Problem description and goals

The thesis project will focus on testing the limits for SiC MOSFET commutation currents and comprise the following key tasks:

1. Study of electric traction system design
2. State of the art literature study on SiC power semiconductor device designs and usage
3. Study of Alstom gate drive principles and practical training in parametrization
4. Training in Alstom power semiconductor test lab equipment and measurement systems
5. Design of experiment – definition of test cases
6. Conduct tests
7. Analysis, conclusions and reporting

Prerequisites: Background in electrical power engineering, power electronics and electric machines. Good analytical skills and systems thinking mindset.

Who are we?
We create smart innovations to meet the mobility challenges of today and tomorrow. We design and manufacture a complete range of transportation systems, from high-speed trains to electric buses and driverless trains, as well as infrastructure, signalling and digital mobility solutions. Joining us means joining a truly global community of more than 75000 people dedicated to solving real-world mobility challenges and achieving international projects with sustainable local impact.

Totally enclosed traction motors normally have difficulties to dissipate heat due to poor cooling. To improve performance of such motors, it is essential to have superior cooling and superior heat transfer within the motor.

Headline: Design for recycling of traction motor
Subject: Environmental Engineering
Description:
Background
In a fast moving and competitive market there is a never ending pressure to deliver SW projects to customers faster, but still maintain the highest quality and staying within the budget constraints.  Our experience is that many projects can be delayed or go over budget due to the fact that the delivery process does not run a smoothly as first predicted.  We would like to understand more detail about why this is occurring and to suggest ways to avoid or mitigate this using modern digitalisation techniques.

Problem description and goals
The purpose of this work is to investigate the process for delivering Propulsion SW to Alstom trains , identify where the bottlenecks are and to suggest where digitalisation could be used to optimise or improve the processes.  Examples might include automation of time intensive tasks, better sharing of information or information management, simulation/digital twins to left shift design work, using AI to replace some activities which are being done by people today etc. This work will provide an introduction into the SW delivery process for a large industrial project. It will introduce the student into the ‘V’ model of working (Requirements to design, to testing, to verification and validation).  These kinds of processes can be found in almost all industrial settings and so it will provide a valuable and transferable overview of how SW is developed. The work can be split up into 3 parts:
1.Interview engineers to build up a picture of the SW delivery process and to identify pain points and bottlenecks.
2. Review and suggest different digitisation solutions which can be applied to streamline the process and remove bottlenecks and pain points.
3. Demonstrate one or more solutions in a proof of concept

Headline: SW SUPERVISOR and SW VALIDATION & SIMULATION
Subject: Engineering
Description:
Who are we?

We create smart innovations to meet the mobility challenges of today and tomorrow. We design and manufacture a complete range of transportation systems, from high-speed trains to electric buses and driverless trains, as well as infrastructure, signalling and digital mobility solutions. As the world of industry 4.0 and the Internet of Things moves into the rail sector more on-line condition based monitoring is being deployed on the trains.  The latest controllers are being developed with the capability to host web pages which can be accessed remotely.

The purpose of this project is demonstrating a condition based monitoring solution for the train traction converter.  The concept is to have a centralised web page which collects data from a number of end nodes and then makes this available for viewing.  The kind of information includes operational status of controllers and contactors, temperatures, voltages, and energy usage in different parts of the system.  The work can be split up into parts:

Headline: Evaluation of open-source hypervisors for safety critical railway applications
Subject: Engineering
Description:
Background
Leading societies to a low carbon future, Alstom develops and markets mobility solutions that provide the sustainable foundations for the future of transportation. Our product portfolio ranges from high-speed trains, metros, monorail, and trams to integrated systems, customised services, infrastructure, signalling and digital mobility solutions. Joining us means joining a caring, responsible, and innovative company where more than 70,000 people lead the way to greener and smarter mobility, worldwide.

With the advent of Systems-on-Chip for functional safety applications and novel levels of multi-core integration, safety products are getting more compact and more energy efficient. One way of achieving high levels of performance and utilization on such a system is to use hypervisors. A hypervisor partitions the hardware resources (e.g., CPU, RAM, peripherals) into several separate virtual machines that can be used independently.

However,  in the safety applications, the hypervisor not only itself should operate in a safe and secure way but should also maintain the isolation between the virtual machines, so that one faulty machine does not jeopardize the operation of others.
The focus of this master thesis is to study and evaluate today’s open-source hypervisors and railway standards such as EN 50128 and IEC 61508-3. With reading the standards the candidate(s) shall devise a metric to evaluate and measure the gaps of available hypervisors to the requirements of safety applications in the railway domain. Also, the candidate(s) shall specify techniques and methods that need to be added to the top-rated hypervisor from the evaluation to meet the requirements for the highest level of safety of EN 50128.

The candidate shall have a good knowledge and understanding of the following areas:
1. Computer Architecture.
2. Realtime systems and Operating Systems
3. Software programming

Headline: Safe Runtime Configuration Data Entry Using Blockchain Algorithms
Subject: Engineering
Description:
Background
Alstom is a leading company in railway signalling providing multiple signalling solutions for costumers around the world. The INTERFLO150 solution is a computer based train control system used in industrial applications. The system interfaces a number of external systems in the process of loading and unloading material. As part of this the configuration of the train requires detailed information about the vehicles within the train including, but not limited to, vehicle length, vehicle identities, brake properties, material capacity etc. Some of these properties are critical to maintaining the safety of the system. Each vehicle in the system is configured with the type of vehicle, identity etc. Today there is no process in which the customer can directly add or remove vehicles or change properties of the vehicle types.

Problem description and goals
The scope of the thesis work is to create a proof of concept a vehicle database where: a user can add, remove or change entries; while a second user can verify the changes. Users sign the changes/verification using cryptographic algorithms. A user (another application) shall be able to load and verify signatures on data without having to load the complete dataset. Strict guarantees are required that no entries have been lost or changed. The loading of data may not rely on external libraries or third party software. The work consists of investigating techniques for signing entries, for example a Merkle Tree; create a simple user interface; create a program for retrieving and verifying data; and show that data cannot be altered or removed. Additional tasks can be to investigate key distribution (PKI) and data backup procedures.

Headline: Propulsion system digital twin linking test with simulation data
Subject: Engineering
Description:
Background
The first step in the design of an electric railway propulsion system for a given application is to define the performance by means simulations. The simulations use physics-based models to determine voltages, currents and temperatures in the various components of the system. In addition to the operational data, key component parameters are also fed into the simulation. These parameters are usually the type or maximum/minimum values for each component in question. When the actual system is built it normally undergoes type testing in a lab environment and compared to the simulations. However, the individual characteristics of the installed components are not necessarily the same as the typical values. This deviation accounts for some of the differences in simulated vs tested equipment. When entering series production and delivery the variance is even more evident. A digital shadow or twin could therefore be a means to quantify the variance.

Problem description and goals

The thesis project will focus on developing a digital twin for part of the propulsion system, e.g. the converter:

1. General study of electric traction systems
2. Study of Alstom’s performance simulation tools and models
3. State of the art literature study on digital twin approaches for electric propulsion systems
4. Develop a digital twin for the selected part of the propulsion system
5. Prepare training data and evaluate digital twin
6. Analysis, conclusions and reporting

Prerequisites: Background in electrical power engineering, power electronics and electric machines combined with data science and modelling. Good analytical skills and systems thinking mindset.

Headline: Propulsion performance optimization by increased utilization of SiC MOSFETs
Subject: Engineering
Description:
Background
The advent of Wide Band Gap power semiconductors, especially Silicon Carbide MOSFETs, has a significant impact in creating more compact, low weight and energy efficient railway electric propulsion systems. One parameter that has not been investigated very deeply is how the theoretically increased Safe Operating Area of these devices relative to their rated current can be used to generate further system level benefits.

Problem description and goals

The thesis project will focus on studying the impact on system level performance of higher SiC MOSFET currents and comprise the following key tasks:

1. Study of electric traction system design
2. State of the art literature study on SiC power semiconductor applications
3. Training in Alstom performance simulation tools and familiarization with Alstom’s latest product range
4. Survey of optimization strategies with SiC devices
5. Definition of simulation cases
6. Performance simulations
7. Analysis, conclusions and reporting

Prerequisites: Background in electrical power engineering, power electronics and electric machines. Good analytical skills and systems thinking mindset.

Headline: Approvals Processes Within Trackside with Regard to the Fourth Railway Package; e.g. TSFS2022:47
Subject: Engineering
Description:
Background
Alstom’s product and system development as well as requirements fulfilment within the railway industry in Sweden must be in line with European legislation, current needs in the Swedish railway network, and needs of the future. With the introduction of the fourth railway package (4RP) in the European Union and corresponding cascading changes in the Swedish legislation, the need for an up-to-date, legally compliant, and applicable hazard log, as the foundation of the safety and certification work within development and customer projects, is emphasised.
Problem description and goals

Historically, the hazard log has been updated and applied on an as-needed basis, which has caused its applicability and usability to vary and its consistency for management of hazards to sometimes be outdated. Now and in the future, however, an update and refreshment of the hazard log to be tailored for the systems and products in place and targeting the daily safety and certification work is imminent. We hope that you want to support Alstom’s work in analysing, updating, managing and integrating the hazard log to be applicable for current and future system needs. Ideally, this is managed in the requirement management tool DOORS, tying to the company processes.

The project will give a good insight into the modernising railway business with related international standards and EU legislation.  It will also include training and active participation in database development within the requirements management tool DOORS. It reflects much of the work carried out by engineers at Alstom when methods and ways of working are developed. However, this project will carry a stronger academic focus on method development, framing questions and reporting. The focus of the method development is how to handle a combination of modern risk management methods, agile development with processes and standards developed in a historic context.

The project will further give insight into both traditional and agile product development strategies, both for the railway industry but also in general. This thesis also provides the opportunity to connect with various authorities within Sweden as well as within the European Union. The emphasis will be on software development. The project will include the application of Swedish and EU legislation and will be in a cross-disciplinary territory containing technology, law, organisation, infrastructure, politics, and economy. This thesis could be done in the Alstom offices at Liljeholmen or from other locations such as the university or at home.

Headline: Relation Between Short-Term Product Development and Long-Term Industry Goals
Subject: Engineering
Description:
Background
The EU works to support the railway industry through promoting technical interoperability, which yields the possibility to cross country borders in a unified manner, as well as legal compatibility, where a vehicle authorised in one country is automatically authorised in the other EU countries. Due to this, Alstom’s product and system development, as well as requirements fulfilment, must be in line with the European legislation, current needs in the Swedish railway network, and needs of the future. At the same time, the product development also occurs in shorter cycles where new hardware and software are developed and commissioned continuously to meet the short-term needs of the market. This way, the international market for signalling systems is governed by both shorter and longer product development cycles.

Problem description and goals
One obstacle for uniting the short and long cycles is that development and safety evidence for railway systems use standards developed by CENELEC (Comité Européen de Normalisation Electrotechnique), which govern the system lifecycle and safety work. The standards follow the V cycle model where each phase is only visited once and are not adjusted for an agile way of working. In addition, the railway industry, despite now being a modern and highly technological field, contains a large amount of conservatism in the mindset around requirements updates, error corrections and product availability for the market. We hope that you want to support Alstom’s work in integrating an agile process with applicable standards and legislation.

The project will give a good insight into the modernising railway business with related international standards and EU legislation. It reflects much of the work carried out by engineers at Alstom when methods and ways of working are developed. However, this project will carry a stronger academic focus on method development, framing questions and reporting. The focus of the method development is how to handle a combination of agile development with processes and standards developed in a waterfall context.

The project will further give insight into both traditional and agile product development strategies, both for the railway industry but also in general. This thesis also provides the opportunity to connect with various authorities within Sweden as well as within the European Union. The emphasis will be on software development. The project will include the application of Swedish and EU legislation and will be in a cross-disciplinary territory containing technology, law, organisation, infrastructure, politics, and economy. This thesis could be done in the Alstom offices at Liljeholmen or from other locations such as the university or at home.

Headline: Teknisk och ekonomisk förstudie för en SMR-baserat vätgasproduktion exemplifierat med pilotprojekt
Subject: Energy and Sustainable Development
Description:
I linje med att dagens lättvattenreaktorer börjar närma sig sin tekniska livslängd samtidigt som det politiska och samhälleliga incitamentet för en omställning av all energi- och industriproduktion till en CO2-neutral verksamhet ökar, aktualiseras frågan om hur den framtida el- och värmeförsörjningen skall utformas för att bilda en kostnadseffektiv, ekologisk och säkerhetspolitiskt trygg grund i Sveriges ekonomi. En viktig pelare i detta anses vara vätgasbaserad industri där vätgasen spelar en nyckelroll som råvara för elproduktionen, fordonsbränsle och diverse industriprocesser.

Problemet är dock att vätgas behöver först produceras i en stor skala under stabila, kostnadsoptimala och planerbara förhållanden. Förnybara energikällor (vind, sol) kommer följaktligen endast begränsat i fråga. Ett rimligt alternativ är vattenkraften; dock har detta kraftslag nackdelen att vara begränsat till några få produktionsplatser i landets nordligaste områden. Småskaliga kärnreaktorer (så kallade SMR, Small Modular Reactor) representerar ett annat alternativ. På grund av sin storlek kan dessa byggas i en relativ snabb takt och nära till områdena med ett stort behov av vätgas. Reaktorerna är flexibla på grund av sitt modulära koncept och kan dessutom leverera processvärme som kan utnyttjas såväl i H2 produktionen som i de anknutna industritillämpningarna.

Det finns redan förstudier som analyserar kostnader av en SMR baserad H2 produktion på en mera allmän nivå (se t.ex. B. Hagert & L. Blomgren, ”Low-Carbon Hydrogen Production Using Small Modular Reactor”, M.Sc. Thesis, 2021) och denna förstudie skall därför fokusera på ett eller några få konkreta H2 användningsområden och SMR reaktortyper. De sistnämnda skall analyseras utifrån aspekter såsom designmognad, tillståndsprocess och kostnad.

Arbetets omfattning:

Projektet är tänkt att genomföras som ett examensarbete. Lämpliga kandidater är civilingenjörsstudenter som har kunskap inom kärnkraftsteknik. Kunskaper inom ekonomi kopplad till energiproduktionen är meriterande.

Preliminära arbetssteg:
1. Val av ett eller flera representativa projekt där man planerar för ett omfattande H2 användningsområde som samtidigt möjliggör placeringen av en eller flera SMR enheter utifrån geografiska randvillkor. Exempel på sådana projekt kan vara stålindustrin, tillverkning av eMethanol, produktionen av vätgas för transportsektorn i ett storstadsområde, med mera. Fokusen skall ligga endast på den svenska marknaden.
2. Undersökning och val av optimala processer för H2 produktion med SMR. Detta kan vara produktion i en elektrolysanläggning med hjälp av el som produceras i en SMR eller produktionen i en termisk process (ångreformering) där SMR reaktorn tillhandahåller processvärmen. Fokusen bör dock här ligga på det förstnämnda alternativet eftersom termiska processer oundvikligen leder till CO2 utsläpp.
3. Baserat på valet i steg 2, ska en lämplig SMR reaktortyp föreslås med hänsyn till den designen som har kommit längst i både utvecklingen och tillståndsprocessen både globalt och i Sverige* och därför verkar bli det mest tids- och kostnadseffektiva alternativet.
* Här skall hänsyn tas till Sveriges (SSM:s) tillståndsprocess för licensering och byggnation av en SMR.
4. Nu skall valet i steg 3 återigen kopplas till tillämpningen identifierat i steg 1 och en mer detaljerad kostnadsanalys av H2 produktionen med en eller flera utvalda SMR enheter genomföras. Potentiella synergier, t.ex. leverans av processvärmen från en SMR reaktor till den utvalda industriprocessen vid sidan av elen för H2 produktionen, skall också inkluderas.

Examensarbetet kommer att handledas av Risk Pilot.

Headline: Scenariobaserad analys av möjligheten till reparation vid härdskadesekvenser
Subject: Engineering physics
Description:
EXJOBB: Scenariobaserad analys av möjligheten till reparation vid härdskadesekvenser

Bakgrund
I kärnkraftsbranschen läggs stort fokus på säkerhetsanalyser och probabilistiska säkerhetsanalyser (PSA) används för att värdera säkerheten ur ett riskperspektiv. Inom PSA analyseras relevanta händelser och händelsekombinationer som är viktiga för säkerheten.
Dock beaktas möjligheten till reparation sällan vilket kan, beroende på scenario, utgöra en hög konservatism och bidra till ett högre riskbidrag än nödvändigt. Därav är det av stort intresse att analysera möjligheterna till reparation scenariobaserat, dvs. undersöka vilka scenarier som kan undvikas att resultera i en härdskada och/eller ett radioaktivt utsläpp till omgivningen.

Arbetets omfattning
Projektet är tänkt att genomföras som ett examensarbete. Lämpliga kandidater är civilingenjörsstudenter som har kunskap inom reaktorteknologi och/eller risk- och säkerhetsanalys (ex. felträd, PSA).
Examensarbetet består av följande delar och är tänkt att utföras av en student. Omfattningen kan justeras beroende på studentens intresse och akademiska bakgrund.
Preliminära arbetsmoment:
• Litteraturstudie av guider för analys av reparation.
• Scenariobaserad analys av reparationsmöjligheten med beaktande av resteffekt (kylbehov) och tillgänglig tid.
• Utvärdering och val av analysverktyg för tidsberoende analys.
• Utvärdering av resultat.
Examensarbetet kommer att handledas av Risk Pilot.

Headline: Metoder för optimering av investeringsportfölj
Subject: Industrial Management
Description:
EXJOBB: Metoder för optimering av investeringsportfölj

Bakgrund
Detta examensarbete utlyses av Risk Pilot i samarbete med Forsmark Kraftgrupp AB, och syftar till att utveckla metoder för optimeringen av Forsmarks investeringsportfölj. Målet med examensarbetet är att kartlägga och föreslå lämpliga utvecklingsområden för Forsmarks nuvarande optimeringsprocess av investeringsportföljen utifrån ett risk-, kostnad- och prestandaperspektiv. Arbetet omfattar litteraturstudie, metodutveckling och exempeltillämpning.
Då ämnet omfattar matematiska metoder inom portföljoptimering och riskteori söker vi en student som har en stark matematisk bakgrund och god analysförmåga. Kunskaper inom statistik/sannolikhetslära och risk är särskilt meriterande.

Arbetets omfattning
Projektet är tänkt att genomföras som ett examensarbete av en eller två studenter. Lämpliga kandidater bedöms vara civilingenjörsstudenter med intresse för matematik och optimeringslära och inriktning mot industriell ekonomi alternativt komplettande studier inom företagsekonomi.
Examensarbetet består av följande preliminära arbetssteg:
• Litteraturstudie över tillgängliga metoder
• Behovsanalys utifrån Forsmarks strategi för tillgångsförvaltning
• Utveckling av optimeringsmetod som beaktar risk-, kostnad- och prestanda
• Tillämpning baserad på en exempelportfölj
Examensarbetet kommer att handledas gemensamt av Forsmark och Risk Pilot och beroende på kandidaterna och uppgiften kan arbetet att utföras i Stockholm och/eller på Forsmark.

Headline: Analys av inter-system CCF i system av modulära reaktorer (SMR)
Subject: Vehicle Engineering
Description:
EXJOBB: Analys av inter-system CCF för SMR

Bakgrund
I kärnkraftsbranschen läggs stort fokus på probabilistiska säkerhetsanalyser (PSA) av säkerhetssystem. Probabilistiska säkerhetsanalyser används för att värdera säkerheten genom att analysera relevanta händelser och händelsekombinationer ur ett riskperspektiv. Ett viktigt fenomen inom PSA är fel med gemensam orsak (eng. common cause failure, förkortat CCF) som ofta bidrar stort till riskbilden. Vanliga avgränsningar vid analys av CCF, innebär att analysen begränsas till säkerhetssystemets systemgränser samt till enskilda reaktorer.
Det finns ett stort intresse för utveckling av den nya kärnkraftstekniken ”små modulära reaktorer” (eng. small modular reactors, förkortat SMR). SMR avser förenkla både tillståndsprocesser samt tekniska säkerhetssystem, samt möjliggöra flexibel utbyggnad av flera moduler av samma typ, ofta på samma plats. Därav är det av stort intresse att analysera den säkerhetsmässiga betydelsen av CCF mellan systemgränser samt mellan reaktormoduler.

Arbetets omfattning
Projektet är tänkt att genomföras som ett examensarbete. Lämpliga kandidater är civilingenjörsstudenter som har kunskap inom reaktorteknologi och/eller matematisk modellering och tillförlitlighetsanalys. Aspekter som bör beaktas är exempelvis feldata för enkelfel och CCF, systemfunktionalitet samt sekvensaspekter.
Preliminära arbetssteg:
• Litteraturstudie av befintliga metoder för hantering av CCF, främst högredundant
• Utveckling av metodik för hantering av CCF med SMR-specifika förutsättningar
• Kartläggning samt avgränsning av säkerhetssystem i SMR
• Genomförande av pilotstudie på valda systemgränser genom att applicera utvecklad metod
• Utvärdering av resultat
Examensarbetet kommer att handledas av Risk Pilot och uppgiften kommer att utföras i Stockholm.

Headline: Analys av CCF för åldrande komponenter i kärnkraftverk
Subject: Vehicle Engineering
Description:
EXJOBB: Analys av CCF för åldrande komponenter i kärnkraftverk

Bakgrund
I kärnkraftsbranschen läggs stort fokus på probabilistiska säkerhetsanalyser (PSA) av säkerhetssystem. Probabilistiska säkerhetsanalyser används för att värdera säkerheten genom att analysera relevanta händelser och händelsekombinationer ur ett riskperspektiv. Eftersom kärnkraftsflottan i Sverige åldras kan PSA eventuellt komma att öka i betydelse. Ett viktigt fenomen inom PSA är fel med gemensam orsak (eng. common cause failure, förkortat CCF) som ofta bidrar stort till riskbilden. Hur fenomenet CCF påverkas vid åldrande komponenter är inte helt klarlagt.
Åldring hanteras oftast genom att analysera påverkan på enkelfelsannolikheten, vilket också kommer att påverka sannolikheten för CCF eftersom denna är definierad med hjälp av enkelfelsannolikheten. Potentiellt ändrar detta också sammansättningen av felorsaker, vilket kan resultera i en oproportionerligt stor ökning av CCF-sannolikheten vid åldring. Därav är det av stort intresse att analysera komponentåldring och dess påverkan på CCF-parametrar.

Arbetets omfattning
Projektet är tänkt att genomföras som ett examensarbete. Lämpliga kandidater är civilingenjörsstudenter som har goda kunskaper inom tillämpad matematik, statistik och tillförlitlighetslära, och/eller risk- och säkerhetsanalys (ex. PSA). Aspekter som bör beaktas är exempelvis feldata för enkelfel och CCF samt hur det tidsmässiga beroendet för dessa ser ut.
Preliminära arbetssteg:
• Litteraturstudie av befintliga metoder för hantering av CCF
• Utveckling av metodik för hantering av CCF med vid åldrande komponenter
• Insamling av data för ett flertal komponenter
• Applicering av metodik samt utvärdering av resultat
Examensarbetet kommer att handledas av Risk Pilot.

Headline: Developing production knowledge and competence in hardware start-ups
Subject: Industrial Management
Description:
Background

Start-ups contribute to the innovation and economic development of Sweden. Despite their contribution, start-ups often struggle to survive in the market, because of the greater difficulties they face, especially at the beginning of their business activity (Serio, Dickson, Giuliani, & Espa, 2020). The main challenge during technology and product development is integrating the design and manufacturing areas in the product development phase (Ferreira, Biesek, & Scalice, 2021). Established large production companies often have structured working methods and development models to support the process. Start-ups have to deal with challenges in both product development and production development.
One reason for start-ups' failure is the lack of market knowledge or industry experience. Not only will the lack of knowledge affect the survival of start-ups, but it is also more likely to affect the formation of new firms, to start with (Marcon & Ribeiro, 2021). Production competence and industrialization are areas often underestimated when discussing the capabilities necessary for the success of start-ups transitioning to established companies.

About the thesis

The thesis work is part of a national project at KTH together with Södertälje Science Park called Production Angels (Produktionsänglar). "Production Angels" helps start-ups go from idea to production i.e., upscaling, going from drawing or prototype to series production.
Through the thesis, you will contribute directly to relevant research supporting hardware Start-ups and SMEs in Sweden and gain practical experience in collaboration with industrial partners.

The focus of the thesis is centered on the transfer of production knowledge and competence. The following research questions are suggested as a starting point:
 How does the transfer of production knowledge to start-ups impact their survival?
 What are the key resources and capabilities essential for hardware start-ups' progression (from idea to production)?

What the thesis includes

- Review of literature
- Collecting empirical data in start-ups and SMEs
- Interacting with and interviewing key stakeholders
- Designing a framework in collaboration with key stakeholders
- Documentation and presentation of results

Who are you?

You are registered in a Master's program in Business or Engineering.
You are two master's students with good knowledge of production management and production development.
You have an interest and/or experience in start-ups business and innovation.
You have a desire to work with real-life challenges and problem-solving.
You like to test new and outside-the-box ideas.
You are driven, organized, and proactive in your work.


Applications must be sent by the latest on Nov 1st, 2022.
Apply by email (to the addresses below) sending your CV(s) and writing your motivation to work on this thesis project.

Contact details:
Seyoum Eshetu Birkie - seyoume@kth.se
Zuhara Zemke Chavez - zuhar@kth.se
Phone: +46 08-790-9485 Ext. 9485

Headline: Handling Irreducibility in a Just-In-Time Compiler
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Java is one of the most popular programming languages in the world and it runs on billions of devices scaling from credit cards to multi-machine servers. Oracle is the main contributor to the Java programming language, developed through the OpenJDK project.

This thesis studies approaches to make the graph-based internal representation of C2 (the JVM's highly optimizing just-in-time compiler) more maintainable, accessible, and amenable to optimizations.

Most compilers represent the code under compilation as a control-flow graph (CFG). A key property of a CFG is whether it is reducible, i.e. it does not contain any jump from outside a loop into the middle of it. Irreducible CFGs arise from the use of unstructured language constructs such as C's 'goto' or Kotlin coroutines, from the application of on-stack replacement techniques in virtual machines, and from compiler transformations such as tail call optimization.
Irreducible CFGs make code analysis and optimization more complex, computationally expensive, and error-prone. For this reason, many compilers transform irreducible CFGs into a reducible form, applying techniques such as node splitting or dispatching, before further analyzing and optimizing the code under compilation.
C2 aims at handling all kinds of CFGs, which has resulted in tens of complex and expensive bugs over its lifetime. This thesis studies different approaches to restrict the structure of CFGs in C2, with the goal of improving its maintainability. Potential approaches include reducibility transformations at different compilation stages, falling back to other JVM execution modes in certain cases, or combinations of these. A successful study has the potential of making Java's main virtual machine more accessible and amenable to further optimizations.

This work will be done on site in the Stockholm office in collaboration with academic researchers who are doing scholarly work on the JVM. For the prospective thesis student, this means the availability of both expert advise on the domain of memory management as well as expert advise on writing, and the academic discipline.
Requirements:

- Must have experience in C++
- Must be familiar with graph and algorithms theory
- Must understand basic compiler theory

This is not an exhaustive list of requirements. Getting in touch with us early is a good way to identify any knowledge gaps that must be filled prior to project start to avoid delays.

Headline: Master Thesis: Deep Gaze on Sport Helmets
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Searching for a fun topic for your thesis? Looking to work in a driven, fun environment with cutting edge technology? Perfect! Let us tell you some more about eye-tracking, because we’re looking for a student to help us explore a deep learning solution for a very exciting new product.

Though for many it sounds like a fun sci-fi topic, eye-tracking has been important across many domains for a while, especially in the 21st century. Eye-trackers can be found contributing to advances in psychology and medicine, integrated into VR and AR systems, soon mandatory for the automotive industry, and with the help of this project, gaining insight into the minds of your favorite sport players! Yes, we aim to add eye-tracking to helmets, and with you on board, we would like to explore a deep learning model that would estimate the gaze of the player.

Deep learning is a member of the machine learning family of methods and it sort of learns like a human – through example. Provided with large amounts of image data accompanied by ground truth annotations, state-of-the-art deep learning models often exceed human capabilities. We can provide the data so that you can work your magic! The aim of this thesis is to apply deep learning to the problem of gaze estimation and compare the performance to that of traditional computer vision methods and machine learning methods.

You will be part of a team of algorithm developers at Tobii working with wearable eye tracking solutions who are excited to hear your ideas and are happily available for discussions and exploring options. Our group of experienced engineers will help you become accustomed to the data and get you familiar with the field of eye tracking.

Specifically, this project could include:

Deep learning solution for gaze estimation
Exploring different state-of-the-art deep learning models
Considering end-to-end gaze estimation vs. PCCR based techniques
and even
Investigating data augmentation strategies for domain adaptation and minimizing data requirements
Benchmarking the computational footprint (processor and memory usage) on relevant hardware (i.e., desktop and/or edge device) and comparing against the baseline
And of course, whatever creative input you come up with!

We are looking for you who:

are currently pursuing a Master’s degree in Machine Learning, Computer Science, Engineering Physics, or a related technical field
feel confident programming in Python
have academic experience and interest in Deep Learning and Computer Vision
It would be beneficial if you:

are familiar with any Deep Learning framework (PyTorch, TensorFlow etc.)
have experience working in Unix/Linux environments
About Tobii

Tobii is the world leader in eye tracking – a computer vision and machine learning based technology that enables a computing device to tell exactly where a person is looking. Eye tracking is used in various applications, including market research and eye-controlled computer interfaces. Headquartered in Stockholm, Tobii covers the global market with offices in the USA, China, Japan, the UK, and South Korea. As our Master Thesis student, you will be working in our Stockholm office.

Next Step

We are curious to know who you are and why you want to do your Master thesis with us. Submit your application through our website including:

CV
Cover letter
Transcripts

Headline: Master thesis: Applying Deep Learning to webcam eye tracking
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Innovation is at the heart of Tobii’s business as a result of its Engineering teams constantly experimenting with the latest technologies and exploring new applications of eye-tracking. Within this project, you will have an opportunity to undertake cutting edge industry research. Tobii is currently using eye tracking technology to support advanced quantitative research in companies around the world. You will have the opportunity to work alongside the team making this happen and supporting them in extending the capabilities of eye tracking as an easily accessible research tool.

What you will do
The core task involves using recent advancements in deep learning to improve the performance and robustness of object-tracking. Recent research in the field of object-tracking has become popular by using a single-shot approach to perform object-tracking in real-time. The thesis worker will be involved in developing a robust object-tracking algorithm by exploring a multi-shot approach, as there could be some possibility for overall performance improvement. Additional research into reducing the model’s memory usage and making it suitable for real-time is also possible. The project will likely involve applying recent deep learning and computer vision techniques.

About you

The project will have a strong research focus and seeks applicants with knowledge of deep learning and a willingness to learn about its application within eye tracking. Depending on their prior experience, the candidate will gain a deeper understanding of both the webcam eye tracking problem and applying deep learning research within modern cloud-based web technologies.

In terms of requirements, we’re looking for a team player with a willingness to learn. Ideally, you have experience in a modern DL framework like TensorFlow, PyTorch, Keras, some knowledge about AWS or similar and some programming experience is a big plus, we use Python!

Your application should include:

Cover letter
CV
Transcripts
We review applications and interview candidates continuously. Please send your application as soon as possible through our website.

Headline: Defending GNSS receivers - implementing and evaluating mechanisms to thwart spoofing
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Master thesis project @ Networked Systems Security (NSS) Group
www.eecs.kth.se/nss

Project title: Defending GNSS receivers - implementing and evaluating mechanisms to thwart spoofing

As the strategical infrastructure relies more and more on Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSSs) for positioning, navigation and precise time distribution, attackers aim at modifying the information the GNSS receiver produces to their own advantage. Attacks showing the power of such methods have been presented against ship, electrical grid infrastructure and critical network timing segments [1, 2].

There is a significant body of literature detecting and resisting attacks, e.g., [3], [4]. The challenge is to leverage all available information and infer when the attack starts, and if possible, compute the location and time in spite the ongoing attack.

Problem to solve:

Your focus will be on implementing, customising, and evaluating schemes that provide detection of the attack, at the victim GNSS receiver; possibly collecting such information to localise the attacker; and depending on the attacker strength, help the GNSS receiver position itself (possibly with lower accuracy).

What to do?

You will research the state of the art in GPS spoofing and signal generation. You will work with BladeRF software defined radio or detailed simulations and assess the defense mechanisms.


Who would be the right person for the project?

- Background (including one or more): You are motivated and you have a good track of developing embedded hardware and software. Additionally, you are curious in developing cutting edge technology with applications to security of GNSS.
- Tools and programming skills: radio systems, SDR, simulator tools, basic security protocols.


Practicalities

Supervisor: TBD
Examiner: Prof. Panos Papadimitratos papadim@kth.se office 4448
Number of students: 1
Academic year: 2022–2023
Nature of the work: 30% literature, 50% practical work, 20% report

How to apply: Please email us CV, transcripts, motivation note (max. 1 page).

Why a thesis @ NSS?

We offer a fast-paced, stimulating environment focused on cutting-edge technology and research of active interest.

Are you interesting in other related projects on security and privacy? Please see https://nss.proj.kth.se/thesis_topics.html for more options and more information.


References
[1] P. Papadimitratos and A. Jovanovic, “GNSS-based positioning: Attacks and countermeasures,” in IEEE MILCOM, San Diego, CA. 2008.
[2] J. Bhatti and T. E. Humphreys, “Hostile control of ships via false gps signals:  Demonstration and detection,” Navigation, Journal of the Institute of Navigation, vol. 64, pp. 51–66, 3 2017.
[3] K. Zhang, M. Spanghero, and P. Papadimitratos, "Protecting GNSS-based Services using Time Offset Validation," IEEE/ION Position, Location and Navigation Symposium (PLANS), April 2020
[4] K. Zhang, E. G Larsson, and P. Papadimitratos, "Protecting GNSS Open Service-Navigation Message Authentication against Distance-Decreasing Attacks," IEEE TAES 2021.

Headline: Dynamic and Privacy Enhancing Data Submission System for PS
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Master thesis project @ Networked Systems Security (NSS) Group
www.eecs.kth.se/nss

Project title: Dynamic and Privacy Enhancing Data Submission System for PS

Problem to solve:
Participatory sensing (PS) or mobile crowd sensing (MCS) allows data collection by many users, devices, and sensors to form and keep up-to-date data on various aspects of everyday life. One example is Google Maps which users running the application submit their location, obtained periodically. The system then creates traffic congestion level reports based on the submitted user data, helping transportation in real time. Such participatory
sensing applications have significant benefits and are already adopted, contributing to our well-being.

By nature of the participatory sensing systems, submitted data usually contains private information about the participating
users, such as location or sensed data. Anonymizing user credentials (e.g., certificates) partially solve privacy problems since the server can still link users semantically, i.e., by estimating the user’s position based on the previously submitted information. One can solve this using number of schemes utilizing, i.e., differential privacy and secure multiparty computation mechanisms. However, users in the data collection process are rarely static, meaning users
move frequently, and users in proximity constantly change continuously. Thus, the usage and integration of such tools
can be problematic.

What to do?
1. Literature review on secure and privacy-preserving participatory sensing architectures, secure multiparty computation,
and differential privacy.
2. Design and implement a secure and privacy enhancing data reporting scheme that enables users to execute
collaborative data submission procedures in fast-changing dynamic user environments.
3. Conduct experiments on the proposed system to evaluate the performance. Discuss the feasibility, utility loss,
privacy and integration within the larger PS architecture.

Who would be the right person for the project?
You are interested in working on cutting edge topics regarding
security, privacy, applied cryptography or distributed systems. You are motivated and capable of working independently, while under the supervision and mentorship of experienced researchers. Grow your skills and yourself as an excellent person and professional by joining us at the NSS group, where you will have a chance to test yourself and influence your own research!
1. Background (including one or more): Experience in modern communication technologies such as Bluetooth, computer security, basic mathematics/statistics. Some mobile development is a plus.
2. Tools and programming skills: Basic programming skills, Java, C++, JavaScript, or Python for the implementation.

Practicalities
Supervisor: Cihan Eryonucu eryoucu@kth.se office 4444
Examiner: Prof. Panos Papadimitratos papadim@kth.se office 4448
Number of students: 1 Academic year: 2022–2023
Nature of the work: 15% literature, 30% design, 40% implementation, 15% reporting

How to apply:
Please email us CV, transcripts, motivation note (max. 1 page).
Why a thesis @ NSS? We offer a fast-paced, stimulating environment focused on cutting-edge technology and research of
active interest. You will be working in a welcoming environment and in close collaboration with experienced senior researchers,
sharpening your technical and teamwork skills.

Headline: Integrating Participatory Sensing Architecture for Securing Applications
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Master thesis project @ Networked Systems Security (NSS) Group
www.eecs.kth.se/nss

Project title: Integrating Participatory Sensing Architecture for Securing Applications

Problem to solve:
Participatory sensing (PS) or mobile crowd sensing (MCS) enables people or devices to gather data using their sensors on various fronts collectively. The ever-increasing number of smart devices with sensing capabilities makes this easier and, gradually, ubiquitous. There are already PS applications for healthcare, environmental monitoring, and urban sensing, with a significant user base aspiring to improve our quality of life.
Secure and privacy-preserving architecture for PS is researched in the literature extensively [1, 2]. Moreover, these architectures offer relevant solutions to various PS system requirements. However, user groups or applications’ interest in such systems was weak, resulting in a low adoption rate by the community. Without developing such components, one can collect various valuable information, such as cellular, Wi-fi, or GPS quality of a region, in a secure and
privacy-preserving manner, with the help of the architectures. collected data.

What to do?
1. Literature review on secure and privacy-preserving participatory sensing architectures and cryptographic primitives
used in them.
2. Design and implement system that utilizes PS architecture for security and privacy. Your system should take an
use-case (e.g. cellular signal QoS) or an already existing system (e.g. an app with PS nature) and then integrate
it to the architecture.
3. Conduct experiments on the proposed system to evaluate the performance. Discuss the integration, efficiency,
comparison with the baseline.

Who would be the right person for the project?
You are interested in working on cutting edge topics regarding
security, privacy, applied cryptography. You are motivated and capable of working independently, while under the
supervision and mentorship of experienced researchers. Grow your skills and yourself as an excellent person and professional by joining us at the NSS group, where you will have a chance to test yourself and influence your own research!
1. Background (including one or more): Computer/network security, basic mathematics/statistics.
2. Tools and programming skills: Basic programming skills, Java, C++, JavaScript, or Python for the implementation.

sharpening your technical and teamwork skills.

Headline: Mobile phone implementation of a GNSS spoofing detector
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Master thesis project @ Networked Systems Security (NSS) Group
www.eecs.kth.se/nss

Project title: Mobile phone implementation of a GNSS spoofing detector

Problem to solve:
Global navigation satellite systems (GNSS) are not only commonly used to provide position and time but are often integrated in highly connected, sensor rich platforms. GNSS spoofing is an increasingly important threat even for low priority devices like smartphones [2, 3]. Nonetheless, modern smartphones are capable sensor
loaded platforms that can be leveraged to execute advanced anti-spoofing algorithms. We want to investigate spoofing
detection by measuring the signal carrier phase when tightly coupled with the IMU measurements and the users unpredictable movement. The work will be based on the results presented in [1, 4] and will consist in an extension of such works for current mobile platforms.

What to do?
1. Study the current state of the art in GNSS spoofing and spoofing detection
2. Develop a tightly coupled IMU GNSS measurement system for a modern smartphone (Android is preferable)
3. Evaluation of the implemented system by measurement on real and simulated signals
4. Explain the finding in a final write-up and present the results

Who would be the right person for the project?
You are an MSc student in Communication systems, Computer
science or Embedded systems at EECS. You are interested in working on cutting edge topics regarding navigation, sensor fusion and digital signal processing. You are motivated and capable of working independently, while under the supervision and mentorship of experienced researchers. Grow your skills and yourself as an excellent person and
professional by joining us at the NSS group, where you will have a chance to test yourself and influence your own
research!
1. Background (in one or more of these areas): computer systems, communication systems
2. Tools and programming skills: Kotlin/Java, android development, basics in communication systems, digital signal processing

Practicalities

We offer a fast-paced, stimulating environment focused on cutting-edge technology and research of active interest. You will be working in a welcoming environment and in close collaboration with experienced senior researchers, sharpening your technical and teamwork skills.

vehicles. arXiv. Available at https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.00140.
[2] Papadimitratos, P., and Jovanovic, A. GNSS-based Positioning: Attacks and Countermeasures. In IEEE Military
Communications Conference (IEEE MILCOM) (San Diego, CA, USA, November 2008), pp. 1–7.

Workshop on Satellite and Space Communications (IEEE IWSSC) (Toulouse, France, October 2008), pp. 167–171.

Headline: Ultraportable FPGA based advanced GPS spoofer
Subject: Computer Science and Engineering
Description:
Master thesis project @ Networked Systems Security (NSS) Group
www.eecs.kth.se/nss

Project title: Ultraportable FPGA based advanced GPS spoofer

As the strategical infrastructure relies more and more on Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSSs) for positioning, navigation and precise time distribution, attackers aim at modifying the information the GNSS receiver produces to their own advantage. Attacks showing the power of such methods have been presented
against ship, electrical grid infrastructure and critical network timing segments [1, 2].

Existing spoofing devices are bulky and rely on the computational power provided by a host computer used to control the spoofing behavior and target. For this reason, the portability of such devices is limited and they are not necessarily convenient to deploy in the  eld [3].

Problem to solve:
Your focus will be on the realization of an ultraportable FPGA based synchronized advanced spoofer for GPS that leverages the capability of a full-duplex SDR (bladeRF) to produce code and
message aligned spoo ng messages in an e client and portable package.

What to do?
You will research the state of the art in GPS spoofing and signal generation. You will investigate the demodulation, decoding and generation of GPS signals in hardware DSP and develop an advanced spoofing device for GPS in a BladeRF software de ned radio. You will test the designed spoofer against currently
commercial GPS receivers to validate the spoo ng system.

Who would be the right person for the project?
1. Background (including one or more): You are motivated and you have a good track of developing
embedded hardware and software. Additionally, you are curious in developing cutting edge technology
with applications to security of GNSS.
2. Tools and programming skills: VHDL, Altera FPGA tools, radio systems, SDR

Practicalities

research of active interest.

References

San Diego, CA. IEEE, 11 2008, pp. 1{7.
